# 灵宝玉监

**Text Title:** *Lingbao Yujian* (*Jade Mirror of the Numinous Treasure*)
**Author:** Unknown. Likely composed between the Yuan and Ming dynasties. Forty-three juan, with an additional juan for the table of contents.
**Source Text:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, Dongxuan Section, Methods Category.

**The *Numinous Treasure Jade Mirror* Catalogue Concludes**
**Scroll One of the *Numinous Treasure Jade Mirror*: Daoist Methods Clarified**
**Clarifying Doubts in Numinous Treasure Retreat Methods**

At the head of the *Scriptures and Methods of the Numinous Treasure*, there are Four Translations, Eight Clarifications, Seven Scriptures, and Eight Latitudes, which encompass the doctrines of all schools. Here, we briefly extract their main principles.

**Four Translations**
The methods of the *Numinous Treasure Scriptures* were first received by the Jade Emperor Dao Lord from the Millet Pearl, inscribed in vermilion script on jade with the Eight Might Dragon Script—treasures of the heavens not transmitted to the lower world. This is the first translation.
The Dao Lord recounted its divine transformations and marvels, placing them at the scripture’s beginning. He exhorted scholars to cultivate steadfast faith and practice, appending this to the scripture’s end. This is the second translation.
The Dao Lord composed the middle section of the *Numinous Writ*, which the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign of Old transcribed as the correct pronunciation. This is the third translation.
During the *Yuanfeng* era of the Western Han, the Queen Mother of the West transmitted this scripture to Emperor Wu, translating the great Brahmā’s speech into the divine land’s language and celestial seal script into unified writing. This is the fourth translation.
Thereafter, Lord Lao descended through successive generations, its transmission gradually spreading. In the second year of *Guanghe* of the Han, the Supreme Ultimate Perfected Xu Junlai transmitted it to the Supreme Ultimate Left Immortal Elder Ge, the Perfected of Mystery. The Immortal Elder transmitted it to the Shangqing Perfected Yang Jun. All were translations from the *Yuanfeng* era, with no further translations. Those who speak of a fifth translation merely add superfluous words.

**Eight Clarifications**
First, one must clarify that the Numinous Treasure is the primordial ancestral *qi*. In the beginning, the vast and boundless Great Brahmā’s true *qi* emerged from non-being into being. All that has form and image is generated and completed by this *qi*. That which forms images and shapes each possesses this *qi*—akin to the Confucian notion of "one thing, one Supreme Ultimate." Thus, humans receive the center to live and each possesses this *qi*. "Ancestral" signifies that which precedes our parents’ birth. Seeking within the body, one must ask: where was this *qi* before the parents’ birth? What are the "parents within the body"? From what was I born? Where is the formless "I"? Only by thoroughly investigating this can one enter non-being and exit being, merging with the Dao in truth.

Second, one must clarify that the *Primordial Beginning’s Unfolding of the Five Chapters*, the vermilion script on jade, and the Eight Might Dragon Script—all talismanic seals in the scriptural methods—originate from this. Scholars must delve into its mysteries, and its efficacy will align with the scriptures’ proclamations.

Third, one must clarify that the *Scriptures and Methods of the Numinous Treasure* all derive from the *Crimson Text of Primal Chaos*. "Primal Chaos" (*hun*) refers to the unmanifest coalescence of the Two and Five. "Abyss" (*dong*) denotes the colorless and boundless. From this, the myriad heavens are transformed, the Three Luminaries illuminated, the Five Scriptures unfolded, and divine spirits universally planted, their transformations endless.

Fourth, one must clarify that the *Scriptures and Methods of the Numinous Treasure* are the origin of all methods. After the Five Kalpas of unfolding transformation, the Three Caverns and Four Supplements encompass thirty-six divisions of scriptures and registers, branching into eighteen thousand chapters. Thus, since Lord Lao’s transmission to the world, the Numinous Treasure’s corpus has been uniquely vast.

Fifth, one must clarify that human existence arises from the Limitless and Supreme Ultimate. Our nature is the Two *qi* and Five Phases; our body is a single point of numinous clarity. That which shines unwaveringly unites nature and consciousness, called the heart. Scholars must constantly preserve the heart, nurture their nature, and in brightness become sagely worthies of the age, while in obscurity become transcendent immortals beyond the world. Aiding and benefiting the hidden and manifest are but secondary matters.

Sixth, one must clarify the wondrous functions of the Numinous Treasure. As the Supreme Ultimate Perfected said:
*"Always at the Supreme Ultimate, grasp the pivot’s mechanism,
In movement and stillness, the divine pearl illuminates the curtained chamber.
Within, the Numinous Treasure appears distinctly,
Like a millet grain suspended in Floating Blackness."*
Thereafter, its applications are boundless in transformation.

Seventh, one must clarify introspection and repentance, contemplating the Dao and pondering the Perfected. Not a single deviant thought should linger in the heart; sight, hearing, speech, and action should always be as if in reverent attendance.

Eighth, one must clarify true cultivation and sincere practice, daily accumulating hidden merits. Whenever the moon wanes at dusk, constellations misalign, the four seasons fall into disorder, *yin* and *yang* lose harmony, pestilence spreads, warfare erupts on all sides, or floods, droughts, and locusts arise, one must perform expiatory rites according to the scriptures’ injunctions, lest one fail the Jade Emperor Dao Lord’s teachings. Naturally, one will excel in the Dao’s domain, merge with the Dao in truth, attain immortality, and fulfill one’s destined role.

**Seven Scriptures**
First: *Great Stabilization of Divine Radiance*. A single point of numinous clarity, immovable in suchness. Vast as the Six Directions, minute as an autumn hair—all reside within one’s divine radiance.

Second: *Penetrating Vision of Subtleties*. The sagely sun and sagely moon illuminate the golden courtyard, their light pervading the ten directions, dispelling all darkness.

Third: *Internal Ingestion of Jade Tablets and Golden Scripts*. These contain the hidden names and secret appellations of the myriad heavenly sun, moon, stars, constellations, and celestial perfected. When held within, spirit congeals and *qi* flourishes; when applied, spirit moves and heaven follows.

Fourth: *Refining and Cultivating Ancestral Qi to Generate the Sagely Embryo and Dharma Body*. "Ancestral *qi*" is possessed by all, requiring no external pursuit. Scholars must constantly contemplate and guard it without loss. With genuine accumulation over time, the sagely embryo forms. Thereafter, one perceives the so-called Dharma Body, exiting being and entering non-being, its divine functions and wondrous applications flowing with creation.

Fifth: *Internal Refinement of the Five Phases*. The formula states: "The Five Phases in sequence generate humans; in reversal, they generate the elixir." The slightest sprouting of desire and passion depletes true *qi*. Scholars must constantly exhale the turbid and inhale the pure, withdraw vision and return hearing, gathering the Five Phases’ true *qi* within the spirit chamber without a moment’s interruption. Thus, one may attain longevity and eternal vision, aid the manifest and deliver the hidden. When spirit moves, *qi* follows—nothing is beyond its application.

Sixth: *Transformation of the Millet Pearl*. Within our bodies naturally resides the Primordial Azure Heaven and Floating Black Earth, and the Millet Pearl—a single grain requiring no external pursuit. One must understand this principle: when dispersed, it fills the Six Directions; when gathered, it does not exceed a handful.

Seventh: *Central Harmonization of the Five Qi, Merging the Hundred Spirits*. Scholars must constantly uphold their resolve to cultivate their *qi*, guiding it to return to the Primal Sea and obey the commands of their original spirit. Thus, in all undertakings, the Hundred Spirits merge as one.

Eighth: *The Eight Latitudes*

1. *Flowing Essence and Jade Radiance*: This is the celestial essence, the upright and unyielding *qi* of Heaven, the numinous treasure of the cosmos. Scholars must seek it within themselves, nurturing it over time, until they behold the so-called five colors surging forth, illuminating the vast expanse. When applied, it repels all, dispels all, delivers all, and accomplishes all.

2. *Cavern Yang Talisman Fire*: According to the *Divine Book*, one harmonizes the *qi* movements of the sixty-four hexagrams with the true *qi* of the thirty-two heavens. Practiced over time, it unites one with the Dao in truth.

3. *Great Brahmanic Qi*: All true immortals transcend through this. The scripture states: "The Great Brahmanic *Qi* circulates through the Ten Directions." If scholars can ensure the Brahmanic *qi* within their bodies flows ceaselessly, even for a single breath, their merit in delivering others will be immeasurable. Ascending in the flesh to transcendence is but a secondary matter.

4. *Recitation in the Three Palaces*: The Three Palaces are the Three Fields. First, one must uphold precepts, restrain emotions, rectify the mind, and sincerely stabilize the true *qi* within. Only then, upon reciting scriptures, will the Infant ascend and descend, the Three Fields resonating with the recitation, and the merit and power align with the scriptural teachings.

5. *Repaying the Origin and Returning to the Beginning*: Scholars must, on the Three Primes, Eight Festivals, Five La Days, and the memorial days of departed ancestors, recite scriptures in accordance with the teachings to fulfill the Way of repaying the origin and returning to the beginning. For spring and autumn sacrifices, one should act according to the family’s means, striving to practice the Way of repaying origins without shame.

6. *Nine Grades of Hidden Merit*: The scripture states: When constellations fall into disarray and the sun and moon lose their harmony, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. When the four seasons fall out of order and yin and yang are imbalanced, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. When the sovereign faces calamity and wars erupt on all sides, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. When plagues spread and the multitudes perish, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. When teachers or friends pass away, one must perform purification rites, offer incense, and recite scriptures. Scholars must diligently practice these to accumulate hidden merit. As merit and virtue accumulate, the names are recorded in the heavens, spirits and gods submit in reverence, and in delivering the living and transcending the dead, every thought aligns with response. Attaining immortality in the flesh is no different from this.

7. *Mysterious Numinous Deliverance*: Scholars [missing character] must, on clear nights, pay homage to the Northern Dipper, swallow the Primordial August *Qi* according to the method, and seek the so-called Supreme Mystery’s Oneness. Guarding their true form, their bodies will radiate light, demons will not dare to intrude, and in moving the spirit to meet the Dao, every thought will resonate with the divine.

8. *Unceasing Deliverance*: The scripture states: "Constantly practice a kind heart." It also says: "Equalize with compassion and love." Upon seeing the widowed, orphaned, solitary, sick, hungry, or cold, one must think of aiding them. If one lacks the means, then broadly encourage others to do so. In years of famine, when corpses fill the ditches; in times of war, when the dead lie exposed; when the unburied are left unwept and wandering souls have no refuge—one must, according to scriptural methods and within one’s capacity, provide salvation. Thus, merit will extend to distant ancestors, and blessings will reach the living. The Supreme Pole Immortal Elder, Perfected Master Sa, Perfected Official Lu, and past patriarchs all devoted themselves to this, not betraying the scriptural teachings.

*Memorials, Petitions, and Documents in Ritual Purification*
The establishment of purification rites requires memorials, petitions, and documents, just as in the secular bureaucracy of the human world. This is the Way of serving humans applied to serving Heaven and Earth and the gods. It is a means of expressing sincerity—borrowing what we possess to resonate with the quiescent and unmoving void. Only then does one perceive its vastness, as if it were above, as if it were to the left and right, making clear that one does not dare regard the gods above and below as nonexistent. Thus, the Way of serving humans is fully applied to serving Heaven, Earth, and the gods. Therefore, before conducting affairs, one must first petition the sovereign of Heaven and the true spirits governing the Three Realms—whether called bureaus, offices, palaces, or courts. For all matters concerning the life, death, sins, and blessings of the world’s people, one must sincerely report each in detail. Whether submitting a memorial, petition, notice, or document, one must act according to the hierarchy of rank.

Some may argue that Heaven is merely the vast expanse of accumulated *qi*—how could there be palaces, courts, officials, and bureaus as in the human world? To this, one responds: You only recognize the accumulated *qi*’s vastness but delight in speaking of palaces, courts, officials, and bureaus as they exist in the human world. Observe the arrangement of the sun, moon, and stars, the alternation of day and night, and the succession of cold and heat—are these not each governed by their own deities? The scripture states: "The Three Luminaries depart, revealing wondrous courts, golden towers and jade chambers, all in serene clarity." The Three Luminaries are the sun, moon, and stars. "Depart" refers to the palaces and halls. "Serene clarity" describes the pristine emptiness and transparency of the golden towers and jade chambers. Moreover, the ancient sage-kings built the Grand Altar to sacrifice to Heaven, declaring, "Dare I solemnly report to the August Emperor." Could one truly claim that the vast expanse of accumulated *qi* is without awareness? Furthermore, the *Monthly Ordinances* always specify, "Its emperor is so-and-so, its god is so-and-so"—are these not each governed by their own deities? The names of palaces, bureaus, offices, and courts in the scriptures originate from when Emperor Wu of Han received the scriptures from the Queen Mother of the West during the Yuanfeng era.

The use of Han-dynasty official titles and bureau names in scriptural translations stems from the occasion when they were conferred upon the emperor. Thus, the establishment of these memorials, petitions, and official documents finds its origin here.

**On the Construction of the Void Emperor’s Altar**
The construction of the Void Emperor’s Altar is indispensable in the rites of purification. The elaborate court rituals of the Mysterious Tenuity unfold here. With each ascent of the altar, as one looks up and down, the vastness of the eight directions becomes vividly apparent—truly, it is as if the boundless presence is above and all around. The ritual closely follows ancient precedent: the ancient kings, when sacrificing to Heaven, invariably built the Grand Altar. Our tradition’s Void Emperor’s Altar is a vestige of that ancient rite. At its center, beyond the three honored positions of the Three Treasures, the four cardinal directions and four corners are occupied solely by the ten directional *Lingbao Heavenly Worthies* and the five directional *Five Emperors*. No other deities are arrayed here, for this is the essence of the sacrifice to Heaven. For three days and nine audiences, one ascends the altar to pay homage, prostrate in reverence, and present memorials—all to express utmost sincerity.

**On the Ritual Objects of Faith Placed Upon the Altar**
The necessity of employing gold, jade, silk, and other offerings to the ten directions on the purification altar signifies the preparation of ritual implements. This is how one demonstrates true reverence. In antiquity, blue-green jade discs were used to worship Heaven, yellow jade tubes for Earth, green jade tablets for the East, red jade tablets for the South, white tiger-shaped jade for the West, and black jade half-rings for the North. Each was accompanied by sacrificial animals and silk, all matching the color of the respective *qi*. The use of ritual objects of faith on the purification altar is likewise a vestige of ancient practice. To abandon this rite would be to regard the deities above and below as insensate—where then would true reverence reside? The quantities used in our tradition differ, following the numbers of the *Five Sons Returning to Geng*: nine for the East, seven for the West, three for the South, five for the North, and one for the Center. The colors of the jade and silk offerings, however, remain unchanged from the aforementioned. As for the scale of the rites, from the Son of Heaven to the common people, the distinctions in rank correspond to differences in ritual observance.

**On the Presentation of Memorials and Petitions**
The practice of presenting memorials is invariably based on the doctrine of the *Ninefold Numinous Paces*. Nine is the number of yang, beginning with one and culminating in nine. Thus, in the *Book of Changes*, yang lines are always referred to as "nine." Heaven is the accumulation of yang *qi* above, hence the term *Nine Heavens*. The method states: to present a memorial, one must project the yang spirit. The officiant must mobilize the ninefold yang *qi* within the body, allowing the spirit within to ascend, borne by this *qi*, to reach the celestial realm and seek the sovereign emperor to whom the petition is addressed. Though the realms of heaven and earth are vastly distant, with a single-minded focus, spirit and Dao become one. When the spirit moves, *qi* follows, and in the stillness of devotion, the response is felt in emptiness—how could this be sought through mere form? A single-minded focus is the yang spirit; the slightest distraction belongs to yin. Be vigilant.

The celestial palaces, bureaus, and courts mentioned are all manifestations of the Heavenly Worthy’s divine transformations, not fixed abodes like an earthly emperor’s residence. The distinction between the Yellow Path and the Black Path arises from calendrical scholars, who established it to observe celestial movements—it is not a rigid division like roads in the human world. Practitioners must not be bound by such interpretations. Some identify the Nine Numinous as Heaven, Earth, Sun, Moon, and the Five Stars, but this is overly contrived and not adopted here. Only the interpretation that names the Seven Stars of the Northern Dipper along with the two auxiliary stars as the Nine Numinous is retained, for the visualization of the Dipper’s handle and its secrets cannot be separated from the Dipper itself.

**On the Use of Seals**
The wonders of *Lingbao* existed before the division of the Two Modes. The scriptures and teachings of *Lingbao* were expounded after the separation of the Three *Qi*. Treasured in the heavens above, they were rarely heard of in the world below. During the Yuanfeng era of the Han, Emperor Wu received them from the Queen Mother of the West, and only then did the teachings spread. As time passed and people perished, the scriptures became fragmented and the teachings declined. Without sagely wisdom, none could avoid losing their innate goodness. In life, calamities befell them; in death, they sank into eternal darkness. Those who clung to their ways without transformation became lingering *qi*, attaching to grasses and trees, becoming malevolent spirits or demons, wandering from delusion to delusion without hope of deliverance. Thus, the teachings branched into methods to assist the upright, dispel evil, aid the living, and deliver the dead. This was the reluctant recourse of those who had already attained the Dao.

The term "method" signifies rectification—rectifying what is deviant. It is akin to governance and punishment complementing virtue and ritual, all for the sake of ordering through the Dao. Therefore, memorials, petitions, official documents, talismans, and proclamations must bear the seals of the celestial bureaus to demonstrate authenticity. Each seal is transmitted by a master, ensuring that the deities of heaven and earth, as well as spirits and ghosts, recognize the authority behind the method being practiced. The divisions and branches of Daoist methods are innumerable, but *Lingbao* is the linchpin of all methods. Its seals are universally applicable.

For instance, in the matter of presenting memorials, though the *Lingbao* method includes a general memorial seal, its inscription originally formed the *Three Heavens’ Joint Contract*, specifically for the ascension of deceased souls. Its origin is unknown, but a master later removed the eight characters for "summoning the soul and the Heavenly Perfected’s talisman" from the seal’s text, repurposing it as a general memorial seal. The ancestral master, *Purple Pole* Tian the True Lord, has already elucidated this in detail. Thus, it is evident that relying solely on the *Lingbao* seal is without flaw.

In the *Zhengyi* teachings, the presentation of memorials employs the *Nine Elder Immortals’ Seal* and twelve lesser seals, which may suffice for *Zhengyi*’s *Heavenly Heart* practices. However, using them in *Lingbao* purification and offering rites is not without issue.

Moreover, consider the various offices of the human world: from the first to the fifth rank, all may submit memorials to the imperial court. Yet beyond the use of their own official seals, there is no separate seal specifically for memorials. By this reasoning, in all *Lingbao* purification rites, all documents should employ only the *Lingbao* seal, which is most fitting. If seals must be used according to specific functions, then the *Divine Tiger* seal may be applied in summoning and restraint, and the *Nanchang* seal in refinement and deliverance. As for seals accompanying registers, their use is left to the discretion of the ritual master, who may employ them as circumstances warrant.

**On Visualizing the Divine and Summoning Generals**
In the practice of all ranks of Daoist methods, visualizing the divine and summoning generals stands foremost. While each tradition has its own explanations for regulating breath, forming mudras, and pacing the stars, relying solely on one method is sufficient for self-cultivation according to its own principles. However, this is not the case in purification and offering rites. For the ritual master’s various generals and officials must all be summoned to assist in the practice. One should first visualize one’s own ancestral *Lingbao* qi as the presiding force, then harmonize the five central qi to unite the hundred spirits. After visualization and summoning, dismissal may proceed without hindrance, for *Lingbao* is the pivot of all methods. If one were to adhere strictly to each tradition’s visualization and summoning practices, not only would this invite unnecessary complexity, but it would also contradict the true function of *Lingbao*.

**On Proclamations, Talismans, and Petitions**
In deliverance rites, talismans, registers, and petitions are used to proclaim to the Three Realms and the ten directions, as well as the courts of the Nine Dark Prisons, to rescue and deliver the deceased. These emerged after the transmission of the *Millet and Pearl Scripture*, when the red-script jade characters were passed down from sage to sage, circulating among humanity as the sun and moon of the netherworld. For the Celestial Emperor, moved by compassion for all beings, saw that in life they indulged their desires, drowning their innate goodness, and in death their karmic consciousness sank into delusion, clinging without transformation. According to their evil thoughts, hells were established to confine their souls and exact retribution. Without talismans to proclaim the Celestial Emperor’s grace, none could attain liberation. Thus, these talismans, registers, and petitions were devised to grant them pardon. The filial sons, dutiful grandsons, righteous husbands, and chaste wives must exhaust their grief and sincerity on behalf of the deceased, beseeching the master with repentance and gratitude, petitioning the Celestial Palace again and again. Only then, in accordance with the *Yellow Register* rank of the Lower Prime, are these decrees issued one by one—much like the imperial court of the mortal world issuing special edicts to pardon sins.

**On the Divine Tiger’s Summoning and Restraint**
The *Divine Tiger Dark Mystery Jade Tablet* is a most esoteric method. Within its text, the secret names of the Northern Dipper are invoked, summoning the descent of *Yaoguang* to illuminate the dark night, reaching all within the Three Realms and ten directions without exception. Its script was personally transmitted to the Perfected Lord Liu Gen of Mount West by the Jade Maiden of the Great One. On the day of the Perfected Lord’s ascension, he sealed it in a stone casket and concealed it within the *Bilu* Grotto of Dragon-Tiger Mountain, where it was rarely transmitted. During the flourishing of the *Zhengyi* teachings, this text reemerged. After being passed down by successive ancestral masters, it became widely practiced.

Thus, the method of summoning and restraint must be strictly observed.

The oral formula states: The Divine Tiger is governed by the Dark Controller of the Northern Dipper’s Northern Culmen. Its jurisdiction is divided into three bureaus:

First, the *Dark Numinous*, ruled by the Star of Greed and Wolf, wherein dwell two spirits—male on the left and female on the right—manifestations of the *Qingyang* and *Tuoluo* deities.

Second, the *Dark Obscure*, ruled by the Star of Great Gate, wherein serve three divisions of envoys—transformations of the Dipper’s *River Culmen*, *Celestial Pivot*, and *Dipper-Striker* spirits.

Third, the *Dark Model*, ruled by the Star of Broken Army, wherein seven *Jade Maidens of Soul-Summoning* and seven *Functionaries* reside—manifestations of the yin and yang spirits of the Seven Primal Stellar Palaces.

When a person dies, their yin soul falls under the Northern Dipper’s jurisdiction. Those who committed grievous sins in life are confined within the Dipper’s prisons. These prisons are distributed across nine locations, hence called the *Nine Dark Prisons*. Collectively, they are named the *Celestial One Prison*, for *Celestial One* is the generative number of the northern direction. Those who accumulated virtue in life have their names recorded in the Dipper’s palace; upon death, their souls are summoned to the *Southern Blaze Fire Mansion* to undergo refinement and rebirth. Only the wicked are detained in these prisons, where they undergo retribution until their debts are settled, after which they are reborn into other forms. Without the *Primal Dark Obscure Jade Tablet*, none can attain liberation—hence the indispensability of this talisman.

Moreover, one must understand that these prisons manifest in accordance with the sins accumulated by the deceased, each prison tailored to their transgressions for due retribution. They are not fixed enclosures like the prisons of the mundane world.

**On the Ritual of Invoking Light and Dividing Lamps in the Altar**

In fasting rituals, the kindling of lamps is always foremost, for it emulates the heavens and mirrors the earth. Thus, whenever a fast is established, on the eve of its commencement, light is invoked and lamps are divided to replicate the celestial bodies—sun, moon, stars, and constellations. This ensures the inner and outer precincts of the altar are luminously clear, with radiance above and below intermingling, approximating the flowing essence and jade light of the *Great Floating Li Soil*, resplendent across the vast firmament, or the boundless illumination of the *Seven Treasures Grove* that suffuses the infinite worlds.

All exalted sages, perfected beings of wondrous conduct, celestial deities, and infinite hosts of saints then incline their light and turn their divine chariots. How could the transformative power of kindling lamps be a trifling matter?

**On Invoking Light to Dispel Darkness**

The method of kindling lamps to pierce darkness is devised for the souls of the dead, who, once plunged into the heavy yin, languish in endless night. Without the illumination of yang light, their liberation is exceedingly difficult. Thus, one must emulate heaven and earth, kindling lamps and presenting talismans.

To *emulate heaven and earth* means to model the celestial bodies above—sun, moon, stars, and constellations—and to arrange the eight trigrams and nine palaces below, thereby conjoining yang light to dispel the dark, allowing the departed souls to ascend by its radiance. This is not merely for the aesthetic beauty of flickering flames.

With focused intention and unwavering concentration, this act elicits a corresponding response. As for *breaking the prison*, it hinges entirely on the ritual master’s ability to merge their own yang light with the lamp’s glow, connecting it to the yang light of the Nine Heavens to suffuse the Three Realms and Nine Dark Prisons. When light pervades heaven and earth, all who have fallen into darkness may ascend by its brilliance, and in that moment, divine transformations unfold. All prisons thus cease to exist.

**On the Nine Dark Prisons**

The *Nine Dark Prisons* fall under the Northern Dipper’s governance, collectively known as the *Celestial One Northern Prison*. Though distributed across nine regions, each with its own name, they manifest in accordance with the evil thoughts harbored by the deceased in life. They are not fixed enclosures like the prisons of the mundane world.

To *break the prison* does not mean physically smashing its gates or shattering its shackles to release the imprisoned souls. Rather, it is achieved through the wondrous transformations of the *Supreme Lord’s* decrees, talismans, and written petitions, which open the way for their deliverance.

Those who wish to repay their kin must also practice the *Way of Universal Salvation*. The path of cherishing kin, benevolence toward the people, and compassion for all beings should be pursued concurrently. Thus, hidden merit will naturally accrue to the soul being commemorated. If the ritual is performed solely for the sake of the deceased, I fear the *Celestial Thearch* will not show partiality to one or two departed souls.

The method requires petitioning the *Three Heavens*, concentrating the mind toward the *Eastern Ultimate*, and borrowing the *Celestial Worthy’s* wisdom light to illuminate the talismans and petitions, thereby conveying one’s spiritual communion with the Dao. For sincerity in one realm elicits resonance in another.

**On the Salvation of the Blood Lake**

The *Blood Lake Hell* arises from the administrators of the dark yin, manifesting in accordance with the grievances of the deceased. All people owe their ephemeral forms to their fathers’ begetting and mothers’ nurturing. Yet women endure countless hardships from pregnancy to childbirth and nursing. Some die while carrying a child, others perish after giving birth; some leave children behind, others lose their children; some mother and child both succumb during labor, others in the aftermath of delivery. These are all cases of past-life enemies reincarnating to exact retribution. Some women use drugs to abort their unborn children, while others, burdened by many offspring, abandon their newborns. Bereft of the means to sustain themselves, their grievances and resentments remain unresolved. Upon death, their souls are bound to the Blood Lake, where they undergo retribution for eons without hope of release. Only through the establishment of grand fasts can they be delivered.

Thus, the *Numinous Treasure Great Rites* include the *Jade Light* section, dedicated solely to the salvation of the Blood Lake. Petitions are presented, memorials are submitted, talismans are issued, and rituals proceed in due order. First, celestial generals are dispatched to summon the souls; then, celestial physicians are sent to heal their ailments; divine water washes away their filth; and ritual offerings assuage their hunger and thirst. Only then are their attachments dissolved, the path to liberation revealed, and the wondrous efficacy of divine power fully realized through the practitioner’s devotion.

Confucian scholars often claim that upon death, the soul becomes a wandering spirit, while the body decays like grass and wood, incapable of further life. How then could filth, hunger, or thirst cause harm?

Moreover, it is said: even if the netherworld truly possesses prisons, shackles, and fetters—just as the courts of the living world—where would they be established? Little do they know that though the body dies, consciousness remains benighted, and thus the attachments of the mouth and limbs cannot be suddenly forgotten. Furthermore, those who harbor grievances and injustices often yearn for vengeance, their indignant *qi* unable to dissipate on its own. They must appeal to the rulers of the unseen realm to seek redress. If their enemies indeed committed wrongs in life, their own souls cannot find peace, and their *qi*—following the dictates of their thoughts—manifests as prisons. Thus, one cannot claim such prisons do not exist.

**On Summoning the Soul with Banners and Administering Celestial Medicine**
The summoning of souls is an ancient practice, as seen when the living ascend to the rooftop and wail at the moment of death. If one, in life, constantly preserves the heart and nurtures the nature, unperturbed by worldly affairs, then in death the *po* returns to earth and the *hun* ascends to heaven—how could the netherworld hold them in bondage? Only those whose innate goodness and virtuous nature are drowned in passion and desire, rigid and unyielding, fail to return in death to their natural submission to heaven and earth. Their *hun* and *qi* drift aimlessly, lost in delusion upon delusion. Thus, first the Divine Tiger is dispatched to pursue and gather them, followed by the Divine Banner to summon and call them back.

Some, in life, suffer bodily mutilation, grave illness, or torment—yet they fail to realize that though the form may be damaged, the original spirit remains whole. In life, the body gave rise to suffering; now, with the body gone, how can illness persist? But if deluded thoughts are not dispelled, they cling to the illusion of bodily deficiency and lingering affliction. Therefore, one must inwardly cultivate the mysterious transformation, gathering the yang essence and dissolving the yin encumbrances, so that the soul may undergo refinement and be reborn. As the scriptures say, they become "natural beings," possessing distinct forms—not mere clay or wooden effigies, each fashioned into an illusory body.

**On Bathing the Deceased, Changing Their Garments, and Offering Empowered Ritual Food**
The concerns of clothing and sustenance arise from the body. When hunger and cold assail the flesh, thoughts turn to food and raiment. But with the body no longer alive, what use are garments and nourishment? The teachings provide these because the deceased, in life, were bound by karmic attachments, obscuring their innate wisdom and preventing self-realization. They remain preoccupied with the pursuit of food and clothing. Thus, first the Yellow Flower Divine Water washes away their former defilements; then, the netherworld garments and ritual food assuage their hunger and thirst. Only then can they hear the scriptures, receive the teachings, and undergo refinement for rebirth. All such acts—bathing, changing garments, and offering empowered food—are devised for the deceased’s deluded attachments.

**On the Sequence of Deliverance from the Three Paths and Five Sufferings**
In the rites of deliverance, the passage on liberating beings from the Three Paths and Five Sufferings corresponds to the scriptural injunction to "extinguish the Three Evils and ascend beyond the Five Realms." Many traditions perform this after transmitting talismans and administering precepts, but this is not ideal. For once the refinement and deliverance are complete, the deceased soul has already attained transcendence and become a celestial being. To then transmit talismans and precepts, emptying all attachments and returning to the undifferentiated purity of the One, is to ascend into non-action. Why, then, would one wait until *after* transmitting talismans and precepts to deliver them from the Three Paths and Five Sufferings? This is a reversal of proper order. Instead, one should first extinguish the Three Evils, forever severing the Three Paths, and eradicate the Five Encumbrances, forever ending the Five Sufferings—*before* refining and rebirthing the soul. This is the precise and careful approach.

The ancestral masters, in establishing these teachings, surely drew from the *Scripture of Salvation*’s passage on "eternally delivering beings from the Three Paths, Five Sufferings, and Eight Difficulties." This occurs *after* the deceased soul has undergone refinement and attained celestial transformation. The scriptural intent is that once the deceased soul is refined and the living being is delivered, they naturally and eternally transcend the Three Paths, Five Sufferings, and Eight Difficulties—not that one would *then* proceed to deliver them from these afflictions.

**On the Refinement of Water and Fire**
In the *Lingbao* method of deliverance, the refinement of water and fire is of paramount importance. When a person’s life is marked by clarity and integrity, their *qi* whole and principle complete, the true essence of the heart moves in wondrous harmony with the workings of creation. In life, they become sages or worthies; in death, their *po* descends to earth and their *hun* ascends to heaven. For their innate goodness and virtuous nature remain unassailed by worldly affairs, and the ebb and flow of their *qi* follow the natural order. Such lofty beings, who refine true yang and harmonize primordial *qi*, preserve emptiness while embracing existence, embody the mysterious and enter the void. With the Dao perfected and merit accomplished, they transcend the mundane—how could the netherworld ensnare them?

Only the deluded, swayed by emotion, enslaved by *qi*, and shackled by attachment, indulge their desires and ravage their true nature, rigid and unyielding. In death, their karmic consciousness cannot escape, and they sink into the depths of the unseen realm. This is why the method of refinement and deliverance is employed.

Refinement and deliverance involve merging the yin and yang of one’s own body with the yin and yang of heaven and earth, restoring those lost in the netherworld to their original state of yin-yang harmony. The yin and yang of one’s body are none other than spirit and *qi*. Spirit is the mother of *qi*; when spirit moves, *qi* follows. The tangible water and fire employed are symbolic representations of heaven’s image, earth’s form, and the true *qi* of the sun’s essence and moon’s radiance. Talismans are further used to invoke divine transformations, enabling the deceased soul to regain the wondrous coalescence of true essence and attain celestial rebirth. Then, through one’s own awareness, one awakens their awareness; through one’s own enlightenment, one enlightens their enlightenment. Thus, the deceased soul naturally returns to undifferentiated purity, merging with the Dao. Whether in heaven or among mortals, there is nowhere they cannot go. First they are refined, then delivered—hence the term "refinement and deliverance."

**On the Distinction of Ritual Offerings**
The forms of great rites are of three ranks.

**The Three Ranks of Ritual Offerings**

The first is the **Upper Prime Golden Register**. It purifies and pacifies the Two Modes, assisting heaven and earth in their work. Through it, one prays for the eternal mandate of heaven, secures the nation’s auspicious omens, extends the lineage of a hundred generations, and nurtures the altars of state for ten thousand years. Such rites are the province of the Son of Heaven; without an imperial decree, none may perform them.

The second is the **Middle Prime Jade Register**. Lords, princes, and marquises may perform it to strengthen the foundation and pacify the realm, shielding the royal house like a screen. Ministers and generals may perform it to gather blessings and bestow them upon the people, stabilizing and securing the world. It may be employed to harmonize the tripod of governance or to regulate the balance of yin and yang. It is not a rite for commoners.

The third is the **Lower Prime Yellow Register**. When the stars stray from their courses, the sun and moon lose their proper times, rain and sunshine fail their seasons, cold and heat fall out of order, warfare does not cease, epidemics rage, famine and starvation follow one upon another, the dead lie unburied, orphaned souls wander, and newly departed spirits suffer grievances—if one follows the prescribed forms in performing this rite, disasters may be averted, the living receive blessings, and the netherworld is touched by grace. From the Son of Heaven to the common people, all may establish it. For filial sons and obedient grandsons, righteous husbands and chaste wives, who seek to repay their parents and honor their ancestors, extending kindness to all beings—if they devote themselves with utmost sincerity, their prayers will be answered as surely as an echo follows sound. Thus, the rite is conducted over three days of solemn fasting and nine audiences of supplication. The divine majesty is as near as a hand’s breadth, and such devotion should be cherished in the Emperor’s heart. Yet the rite concludes with the offering of the *jiao* ceremony, for it is through this that one fulfills the essence of reverence. It serves to acknowledge the ascent and descent of the gods above and below, and to atone for past transgressions.

Since the establishment of the fast, though one’s devotion in facing the divine may be unwavering, those who preside may be enslaved by worldly concerns, and those who serve may let their minds drift with the tasks at hand. They may fail to remain vigilant from beginning to end, or may cut corners due to crude simplicity. The offerings of milfoil and orchid may not suffice to display sincerity, nor the silk cords and jade pendants to fulfill the full courtly ritual. Thus, this *jiao* offering is indispensable for expressing remorse and seeking forgiveness.

Moreover, the fast begins with the initial proclamation and ends with the ninth audience. The gods who serve in their offices have labored long; only with a proper conclusion can their work be complete. It may well be counted as their merit, and thus this *jiao* offering is also indispensable for recompense.

As for the number of positions in the ritual:
- Three thousand six hundred,
- Two thousand four hundred, or
- One thousand two hundred—

Or, in smaller scales:
- Three hundred sixty,
- Two hundred forty, or
- One hundred twenty—

These correspond to the ranks of the Golden Register, Jade Register, and Yellow Register, each with its own gradations. From the Son of Heaven to the common people, each observes different ritual measures according to their station.

*Lingbao Yujian*, Scroll One, concludes.
*Lingbao Yujian*, Scroll Two.

**The Gate of Ritual Procedures for Daoist Retreats**

The Dao’s wonders are profound and subtle, its transformative power boundless; yet without written teachings, none may cross to the other shore. Once the master’s intent is made clear, the Dao does not act in vain. How much more so with the Primordial *qi* of the Numinous Treasure, which governs the myriad heavens, universally bestows upon the ranks of lords, and has propagated its great transformation across ancient and modern times? It is the refuge of both the living and the dead. Thus, in the teachings for delivering the world, there exists an orderly sequence.

First, one must address the High Merit Master to secure the ritual’s peace, submitting a petition to the presiding officiant. Upon the master’s consent, an auspicious day is chosen for the rites. It is fitting to first dispatch memorials to the Three Heavens, pledging alliance with the Ten Poles. Then, in due order, one establishes bureaus for drafting memorials, petitions, talismans, and registers, as well as for the inner and outer participants—both the covenanted and the laity—who must fast, bathe, purify their garments, and rectify their headdresses. With unified intent and shared sincerity, they prepare the ritual implements and offerings. A month in advance, memorials are submitted to the celestial ministries, notifying the relevant offices. The petitions are reviewed, and talismans and registers are activated.

Thereafter, the assembly of Daoist adepts gathers to succor the shades of the dead. Images are set up, altars arranged, scriptures recited, and repentances offered. Whether through the Ten Cycles of Scriptural Recitation or the Nine Transformations of the *Shengshen* Rites, the primary memorials are presented, petitioning the vast heavens. According to the merit and capacity of the participants, the rites proceed in sequence.

In all cases, the establishment of good karmic conditions depends upon the presiding officiant. It is essential to rectify the mind and cultivate sincere intent, to penetrate the mysteries and fathom the subtleties. Outwardly, one must embody solemn dignity; inwardly, illuminate the nature of the Dao. Only then may humans and celestials alike look to it as their refuge, the hidden and the manifest alike take it as their shelter. With such devotion, responses will surely come, and no distance will remain unreachable. Yet how could the marvelous subtlety of the Dao and its methods be easily fathomed?

Originally, from the vast darkness of the primordial *mingxing* and the boundless expanse of the Great Brahmā, where no light yet shone, the One *qi* first divided, and the mysterious and the yellow took form. Thus, the celestial wheel and the earthly carriage were modeled after them. The Two Modes settled into their positions, the Three Luminaries shone forth, and the sun, moon, and stars followed the celestial patterns in their courses—hence the arrangement of lamps and torches in sequence. The Five Phases spread forth, the myriad forms unfolded, yang descended and yin ascended, their harmonious union following the Dao—hence the sounding of bells and jades in order. For the welcoming of divine palanquins, the purification of the ritual space, the clearing of dust by the Wind Earl, and the sweeping by the Rain Master—hence the consecration of water and the prohibition of the altar in due course. With the Four *qi* in clarity and the myriad heavens in perfect brightness, the spirits are moved and sincerity is conveyed—hence the invocation of the sages and the presentation of prayers in sequence. The auxiliary altars and steps each have their designated offices, and thus they are comforted and made ready for summoning and service—hence the establishment of the various bureaus in order.

The ten kinds of lonely souls and the nine springs’ lingering shades are assigned their domains and provided with dwellings—hence the Cold Forest and Reed Enclosure in sequence. The divine dragons and courier officials can reach the deepest springs; jade tablets and golden talismans must rely on their transmission—hence the sacrifices and prayers to the dragon couriers in order. To magnify the Dao and its virtue, to enlighten humans and celestials, to take goodness as one’s teacher and rely solely on virtue—hence the establishment of the Mystic Awakening Tent in sequence. In conducting retreats and practicing the Dao, in audience with the Emperor and audience with the Perfected, one must observe solemnity in ascent and descent, and never slacken in progress or cessation—hence the appointment of officials and the division of duties in order. Each must reverently attend to their tasks, never neglecting their office. Pledging oaths to the Three Officials and forming covenants with the Five Emperors—hence the ranking of offices and the sealing of alliances in sequence. To guard against wrongdoing and halt evil, to restrain deviance and preserve sincerity, to avoid error and forgetfulness, upholding the constant norms and teachings—hence the recitation of the Ten Precepts of the Dao in order. Solemn dignity is the cornerstone of virtue; in all movements and interactions, one must strive to remain vigilant—hence the imposition of prohibitions and penalties in sequence. Before undertaking any rite, one must begin with the proper preliminaries, invoking the Perfected Masters to guide and convey one’s reverent sincerity—hence the memorials to the Master’s Tent in order. Rolling up the curtains and ascending the steps, one pays homage to the sacred and attends the Primordial—observing the rites between lord and subject, and maintaining reverence within and without—hence the rolling up of curtains and the transformation of the ritual space in sequence. The Three Altars share a single sacred precinct, revered by the myriad spirits, encircling the August Jade Emperor in audience—hence the establishment of the altars and the preliminary rites in order. Flying one’s spirit to audience with the Emperor, conveying one’s sincerity and devotion, invoking the descent of *qi* and light, delivering the dead and absolving sins—hence the presentation of memorials and petitions in sequence. The One Perfected congeals into talismanic script, the Brahmā *qi* forms its patterns, universally proclaiming to the ten directions and illuminating the long night—hence the distribution of talismans and tablets in order. The Fengdu and Mount Tai, which restrain and govern the dead, the dark bureaus and the gates of the underworld—all depend upon their presiding officials—hence the offerings to the underworld officials in sequence. The Primordial Beginning’s ancestral *qi* and the Numinous Treasure’s wondrous light transform and deliver the shades of the netherworld, halting their imprisonment and ending their trials—hence the lighting of lamps and the breaking of the prisons in order. With *qi* uniting *qi*, with spirit meeting spirit, the One Perfected shines resplendently, universally embracing all existence—hence the summoning and gathering of souls in sequence. When souls arrive, their lingering attachments remain; cleansing their impurities and purifying their forms, their spirits are restored to wholeness—hence the arrangement of curtains and the spreading of transformations in order. The wondrous *qi* of the Three Luminaries and the five-fragrance orchid broth bathe and irrigate the body and spirit, revealing their marvelous origins—hence the bathing and purification of impurities in sequence. Before one forgets the phenomenal, one must don the garments of the Perfected. With dignified bearing and solemn courtesy, one pays homage to the Three Realms—hence the changing of robes and the morning audience in sequence. The wondrous delicacies of the Five Kitchens and the eight flavors of rare offerings transform without limit, fulfilling every thought—hence the consecration of food and the presentation of offerings in sequence. Hearing the scriptures and listening to the Dharma, the stagnant souls and sunken spirits awaken to the Dao and ascend to Perfection, receiving deliverance—hence the distribution of food to succor them in sequence.

The establishment of the retreat thus proceeds in orderly fashion. On the following day, the morning rites commence, each with its established norms. The morning rites occur thrice daily, progressing from three to nine sessions, with nine invocations, nine memorials, nine repentances, and nine talismans. Outwardly, one harmonizes solemn dignity; inwardly, one exhausts sincerity and reverence. In the retreat, one advances through the ritual meals, expounds the precepts, transmits the talismans, verifies the fruits of attainment, ascends to Perfection, severs the corpse, delivers the household, the celestial spirits receive the treasury, the Great Cavern returns the spirit, the assembly recites the jade scriptures, and the High Merit Master performs the inner rites. Next, the water pool and fire marsh are established, aligning with the essence of the sun and the radiance of the moon. The Perfected oversee the deliverance of the living, restraining demons and ensuring protection. The alchemy of generation and transformation, combined with the incantation of the Ninefold *Jiji*, perfects the threefold shedding of the mortal form, giving birth to immortals anew, re-engendering the sacred embryo in the empty valley, and ascending the yang *qi* to the Mysterious Pass.

Upon receiving the Dao and donning the yellow robe, one transcends the mundane and enters sagehood. Thereafter, the altar is dismantled, the mats are rolled away, the memorial tablets are presented, and the dragon talismans are cast into the waters. Gratitude is offered to the Mysterious One, and the master is sent off, with officials resuming their duties. Offerings are made to repay kindness, and rituals are held to redeem lives and release the living.

This should be measured against ancient precedents while adapting to the present, linking past and future, extending from inner cultivation to outer service, and advancing self-realization to benefit others. Should any omissions or errors occur, they must be diligently repaired. All fellow practitioners—ought you not strive with utmost effort?

**Sequence of the Grand Offering Ritual**
The *Zhai* Official first delivers the address, presenting the ritual gift before the High Merit Master’s altar. The High Merit prepares the invocation and submits it to the Three Celestial Gates, requesting the establishment of the Memorial Petition Bureau, the Talisman-Thread Bureau, and the Universal Salvation Bureau. A second petition is then submitted to the Three Celestial Gates, to be presented before the Golden Portal and the Imperial Master, who issues decrees to all relevant offices. A third petition is submitted to the Three Celestial Gates to fix the date for the memorial presentation, halting winds and ceasing rains.

Next, a preliminary memorial and proclamation are issued, the canopy of armor is dispatched, and banners are raised at the four boundaries. The Divine Tiger Hall is established, along with the Local Domain Bureau, to receive and aid orphaned souls. A memorial petition is initiated, and the Banners of Proclamation, Returning Yellow, and Transcending Spirits are raised. Alternatively, the *Chao Tian Chan* or *Jiu You Chan* may be performed. The *Ten Recitations of the Scripture of Salvation* and the *Nine Cycles of Engendering the Spirit* are recited. The Five Paths of the Spirit Lamps are opened and consecrated.

**Sequence of the *Jiao* Enclosure Ritual**
The Dao assembly gathers at the *Jiao* enclosure site. The Keeper of the Bell intones the invocation to the Heavenly Worthy of Salvation by Sound. The assembly responds with the Fourfold Chant, and the Announcer recites the Water Verse, followed by the Incense Verse. The prayer to inaugurate the sacred is offered, and the Light-Opening Verse is chanted. The Keeper of the Bell invokes the Jade Treasure Heavenly Worthy of the Highest Heaven. The High Merit and officials proceed to the Eastern Gate. The Announcer proclaims the address, and the verse is chanted.

Next, they proceed to the Southern Gate, where the Keeper of the Bell invokes the Heavenly Worthy of Myriad Blessings of the Mysterious Truth. The Announcer proclaims the address, and the verse is chanted. They then proceed to the Western Gate, where the Keeper of the Bell invokes the Heavenly Worthy of Supreme Mystery. The Announcer proclaims the address, and the verse is chanted. Next, they proceed to the Northern Gate, where the Keeper of the Bell invokes the Heavenly Worthy of the Jade Dawn of the Mysterious Above. The Announcer proclaims the address, and the verse is chanted. Finally, they proceed to the Central Gate, where the Keeper of the Bell invokes the Heavenly Worthy Who Transcends the Immortal Realms. The Announcer delivers the comprehensive address, and the High Merit recites the incantation as the assembly chants the ascent to the Heavenly Paradise. The Dao assembly circumambulates, reciting the *Scripture of Salvation*. The Hua Xia procession leads to the ritual site, where the Azure Mystery Canopy is raised, and the Radiance-Returning Banner is displayed.

**Consecration of Lamps, Instruments, Altar Establishment, and Petition to the Dragon Officials**
The Dao assembly gathers in the Master’s Hall. The Master of Rites guides the *Zhai* Official to offer incense and perform three bows before returning to their position. The Attendant at the Censer leads the ranks to the altar. The Attendant at the Censer guides the ranks in a leftward circumambulation of the Celestial Wheel Lamp Altar. The Keeper of the Bell intones the invocation to the Heavenly Worthy of Limitless Salvation. The assembly responds in unison as the High Merit recites the verse:

*"The Primordial Beginning reveals the Mysterious, the Numinous Treasure’s original scripture,
Unfolding the supreme teaching, the Ten Recitations of Salvation."*

Each line is echoed by the assembly.

Next, the banners of the Thirty-Two Heavens are lowered, with the Yellow Banner at the forefront. The Keeper of the Bell invokes the Heavenly Worthy of Salvation in All Directions. The assembly responds in unison as the High Merit recites the verse:

*"The Supreme Lord of the Dao commands the Kunlun,
With a single divine talisman, the dead are delivered."*

Each line is echoed by the assembly.

Next, the banners of the Twenty-Four Prisons are lowered, with the Crimson Banner at the center. The High Merit proceeds to the Earth Gate, transforms into the divine form, paces the *fang* steps, and sprinkles water. The Four Spirit Lords and the local ritual officers are summoned. The Announcer proclaims the petition to borrow the earth, and the High Merit swears the oath, sprays water, and issues the command. The Master of Rites guides the *Zhai* Official to the East to offer incense. The High Merit approaches the Eastern Quarter to present the local talisman and the altar command. The Keeper of the Bell intones the devout prostration to the Nine *Qi* Heavenly Lords of the East. The Announcer proclaims the Eastern talisman of borrowed earth. The High Merit issues the Eastern altar command.

Proceeding to the South, West, North, and Center, the same rites are observed as in the East. The High Merit ascends the Cavern Tablet to offer incense and returns to position. All officials resume their places. The Keeper of the Bell invokes the Heavenly Worthy of the Three Luminaries’ Bright Illumination. The High Merit delivers the address and bows to invite the radiant manifestation. The Attendant of the Lamps proclaims the division of the lamps. The Dao assembly declares the lighting of the lamps. The lamps are then kindled. The Attendant of the Scriptures proclaims the consecration of the bells and chimes. The officers are summoned according to the prescribed form. The Keeper of the Bell invokes the Jade Clarity Heavenly Worthy Who Sweeps Away Defilement. The assembly responds in unison as the Master of Rites guides the *Zhai* Official to offer incense. The High Merit kneels to present the memorial, reciting the address to dissolve defilements and proclaiming the memorial. The High Merit dispatches the officers as prescribed. The Burning Memorial Hymn is chanted. The Precentor transforms into the divine form, paces the *fang* steps, and summons the officers. The Announcer proclaims the petition to dissolve defilements. The Precentor consecrates the water, purifies the altar, and seals the boundaries.

If the altar is to be established, the subsequent rites follow the *Altar Establishment Protocol*; otherwise, the High Merit proceeds here with the altar-sealing ritual. The Keeper of the Bell chants the Hall-Opening Hymn. The High Merit ascends the Cavern Tablet to offer incense. The Master of Rites guides the *Zhai* Official to offer incense and perform three bows. The Keeper of the Bell intones the reverent observance of each participant. Next, the Keeper of the Bell intones the refuge in the Three Treasures. The assembly, holding tablets before their hearts, initiates the rites as prescribed. The Announcer invokes the incense and inaugurates the ritual, proclaiming the intent of the offering. The Master of Rites guides the *Zhai* Official to offer incense and perform three bows.

From this point onward, if establishing the Altar of the August Void, follow the *Altar Establishment Protocol*. The Keeper of the Bell intones the chant of the Dao. The Attendant at the Censer leads the ranks in the Hua Xia procession, burning incense in the expansive hall. The Precentor leads the various bows to the masters, entering the rites as prescribed. Upon establishing the Altar of the August Void, the Three Treasures are invited. The High Merit summons the officers, paces the Dipper steps, and seals the altar. The plaques for each gate are affixed, and the rites proceed according to the protocol.

If the Altar of the August Void is not established, the rites conclude after the Announcer’s inaugural proclamation. The Attendant at the Censer leads the ranks out. The Supervisory Altar is constructed, with six outer curtains. Next, the Canopy of the Nine Heavens is suspended, and the Banner of Altar Establishment is raised. Alternatively, the Dragon Officials may be petitioned at this juncture.

The Attendant at the Censer then leads the ranks back to the ritual site. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Minor Exit Hymn*, recites the concluding dedication, and guides the assembly to the Master’s Hall. The Master of Rites guides the *Zhai* Official to perform three bows. The Keeper of the Bell announces the completion of the inaugural rites, and all officials resume their positions. The assembly performs the concluding bow. The Jade Tablet of the Divine Tiger is dispatched.

The assembly of Daoists gathers at the Divine Tiger Altar. The High Priest purifies with lustral water, transforms into the divine, and treads the Divine Tiger’s *gang* steps. The gates are sealed, and the generals of the Divine Tiger are summoned. The Attendant at the Censer recites the *Jade Tablet* offering text three times. The proclamation of the *Jade Tablet* and the memorial for sealing the petition are announced. The High Priest sprinkles water and treads the Dipper, dispatching the official bearing the *Jade Tablet*. Then, with a new fan, he fans the *Jade Tablet* several times, and the ashes rise with the fan’s breeze, revealing the numinous radiance of the Northern Dipper, illuminating the ten directions and the Three Realms. The High Priest visualizes and employs this, reciting scriptures. The preceding is dedicated.

The altar’s resources are prepared, and the assembly of Daoists gathers in the Master’s Hall. The Master of Rites guides the *Zhai* Official to offer incense and perform three bows. Next, the High Priest approaches the Master, offers incense, and returns to his position. The Keeper of the Bell chants, and each person conducts themselves with reverence. The Attendant at the Censer presents incense before the ranks, advances to the High Priest, performs the full prostration, and kneels; an attendant may also deliver the words on behalf of the *Zhai* Official. Alternatively, a memorial may request the Master’s ascent to the altar. The High Priest assents, and the Attendant at the Censer expresses gratitude for the consent. The altar officials then return to their positions. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Invitation of the Perfected Master for the Purification Rites*. Next, the *Cloud Chariot Hymn* is chanted. The Keeper of the Bell intones the *Celestial Worthies of the Fragrant Forest Preaching the Dao* four times. The High Priest takes incense and performs the concluding bow. The High Priest then points to the seat, delivers the dharma discourse, and ascends. Incense is offered, the Dao is expounded, the assembly sits to listen, and gratitude is expressed. He descends from the seat.

The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Jade Clarity Heavenly Worthy Dispelling Impurities* once. The Lector recites the *Dispelling Impurities Mantra*. The Keeper of the Bell then chants the *Golden Perfected One Expounding the Teachings Heavenly Worthy*. After four responses, the Attendant at the Censer leads the assembly to stand in order before the curtains of the Two Masters. The Keeper of the Bell chants, and each participant demonstrates reverence and faith. The High Priest kneels to petition the Two Masters. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Purification Rites Hymn* and the *Cloud Chariot Hymn*. Next, the hymns for the Two Masters are chanted. The High Priest delivers the invocation to initiate the mystery. The Announcer reads the memorial.

Then, they proceed to the curtains of the Five Elders, the Three Officials, the Three Masters of the Numinous Treasure, the Three Masters of the Orthodox Unity, and the Supervisor of the *Zhai*. At each curtain, the Keeper of the Bell chants the *Purification Rites Hymn*, followed by the *Cloud Chariot Hymn* and the *Invitation Hymn*. The Announcer reads the memorial. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *General Memorial-Burning Hymn*. The Attendant at the Censer leads the assembly to stand in order before the curtains of the Two Masters. The High Priest delivers the words for the supplementary roles. The Announcer proclaims the rites for the supplementary roles, and the officials line up to bow and kneel. The Directing Official of the Altar distributes the role tablets; each official receives their tablet, bows three times, and returns to their position in order.

They proceed to the curtain of the Three Officials, where the Announcer reads the *Alliance Oath*. They then return to stand in order before the curtains of the Two Masters. The Lector calls upon all officials, each pressing their heads to the ground in silent reverence to the ten directions, bowing once to each, beginning from the north and circling to complete the homage to all ten directions, devoutly receiving the precepts. Next, the High Priest faces forward and sounds the ruler. The Ten Precepts are recited. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Hymn of Wisdom*. After the High Priest concludes the precepts, the *Hymn of Upholding the Precepts* is chanted. The Lector intones, and all officials sit evenly to hear the proclamation of the *Disciplinary Regulations*. The High Priest announces the *Regulations and Penalties Tablet*, and the Supervisor of the *Zhai* delivers the words. The Master of Rites invites the *Zhai* Official to offer incense.

The High Priest establishes the altar and makes the petition; the Keeper of the Bell chants the *Daoist Invocation*, and the Attendant at the Censer chants the *Praise of the Hua-Xia*. Next, the assembly is led to burn incense at the outer enclosure and proceed to the curtain. The High Priest and the *Zhai* Official offer incense before the curtain, bow three times, and kneel to petition the *Memorial for Communicating with the Perfected*. The Announcer reads the memorial, and the High Priest delivers the words to announce the *Talisman for Transforming the Realm*. The words of repentance are proclaimed, and the talisman is announced; the High Priest recites the talisman’s incantation. Next, the *Scroll-Raising Text* is read, the Keeper of the Bell chants the *Reverent Homage to the August Rites of the Void Sovereign*, the curtain is raised by the Directing Official of the Altar, and the High Priest and the *Zhai* Official bow three times. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Heavenly Worthy of Golden Countenance and Jade Form*.

They proceed to the Three Clarities. The High Priest offers incense to the Three Realms, and the Keeper of the Bell chants the *Reverent Homage to the Three Clarities*. The Attendant at the Censer and the Keeper of the Bell lead the High Priest forward. Next, the Lector enters the main gate in order, proceeding to the earthly portal; the High Priest enters with the portal incantation and ascends the altar in sequence, standing in order. Next, incense is offered to the ten directions, and the Keeper of the Bell chants the *Reverent Homage to the Highest Nine Qi Heaven*, beginning with the *Heavenly Worthy of the Numinous Treasure of the Supreme East*. Then, the southeast, south, southwest, west, northwest, north, northeast, above, and below are invoked in turn. The Keeper of the Bell next chants the *Incense-Burning Hymn*. The High Priest approaches the grotto table, offers incense three times, recites the incantation three times, visualizes the use, returns to the altar, kneels before the censer, recites the incantation, and burns the talisman.

The Lector chants the *Homage to Each Master*, and the High Priest proclaims the *Guardian Spirit Mantra*. The Lector intones, and the ritual drum is sounded twenty-four times. The High Priest opens the censer, and the Lector chants the *High Priest’s Inspection of the Officers and Soldiers*, who emerge according to the rites. The High Priest emerges as an official. The Lector chants the *Proclamation of the Dharma Ranks*. The High Priest enters the *Altar-Establishing Rites*. The Keeper of the Bell and the Attendant at the Censer alternate in chanting the *Devout Homage to the Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions*. By day, they begin from the east; by night, from the north. The Keeper of the Bell next chants the *Homage to the Feet*, and each participant devoutly repents. The Lector gathers the Heavenly Worthies of the Ten Directions to sit in repentance. Next, the Keeper of the Bell chants the *Step Through the Void*, three invocations and three bows.

The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Heavenly Worthy of the True Writ’s Pacification*, and the High Priest kneels to petition the True Writ. The Master of Rites leads the *Zhai* Official to the east, where incense is offered, and they kneel and bow. The Attendant at the Censer leads the High Priest to the east. The Keeper of the Bell follows, chanting the *Nine Qi Heavenly Lords of the East*. After one response, the Keeper of the Bell next chants the *True Writ of the East* and requests the master to pacify it. The High Priest recites the *Pacification Incantation of the True Writ of the East*. They proceed to the south, west, north, and center, each performed as before. Next, the *Golden Dragon Pacification* is chanted four times, or the memorial may be presented here. The Lector chants the *Proclamation of the Dharma Ranks* again. The High Priest re-enters the rites. The words of repentance are proclaimed, and the High Priest prostrates. The memorial is burned. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Memorial-Burning Hymn*. The High Priest rises from prostration, re-enters the rites, and expresses gratitude. The Keeper of the Bell and the Keeper of the Bell Chime strike the metal and jade instruments in alternation.

The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Heavenly Worthy of the Jade Talisman’s Absolution of Sins*. The Master of Rites invites the *Zhai* Official to offer incense. The High Priest petitions for the talisman’s announcement and performs the *Talisman of Salvation from Suffering*, the *Nine Dragons Talisman*, the *Talisman for Breaking Hell*, the *Talisman for Delivering the Hidden Souls*, the *Flowing Light Talisman*, and the *Register of Command and Absolution*. All the above talismans are for delivering the hidden and dark realms and must be performed here. The proclamation of the nine-morning talismans, all of which pertain to the ascent and deliverance, must be included in the announcement during the morning petition. The repentance is proclaimed while kneeling, and the High Priest recites the incantations for each talisman. The High Priest next summons the generals and proclaims the talisman’s mandate. The High Priest holds the water vessel outward, silently visualizing its use. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Talisman-Dispatching Incantation*. All join in, and the Master of Rites invites the *Zhai* Official to face outward, bow toward the altar, and burn the tablet and talisman. The *Dragon Youth* is transformed.

The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Heavenly Worthy of Carefree Bliss*, and they turn inward. Next, the *Twelve Vows* are chanted. The Lector chants the *Visualization of the Spirit and Gathering of Incense*. The High Priest returns to the censer. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Exiting the Hall Hymn*, and they circumambulate down from the altar. The Attendant at the Censer leads the assembly to the curtains of the Two Masters. The High Priest offers thanks, and the Announcer delivers the *Dedication*. The Lector chants the *Supervisor’s Admonition*, and the Supervisor of the *Zhai* proceeds to the curtain to kneel and petition. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Heavenly Worthy of the Dao, the Scriptures, the Masters, and the Treasures*. They proceed to the curtains of the primary and secondary ranks, open them, and begin the scripture recitation. They return to the Master’s Hall. The Master of Rites invites the *Zhai* Official to offer incense and bow three times. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Hymn of Taking Refuge in the Orthodox Dao*. Next, the *Altar-Establishing Rites Concluded* is chanted, and all officials perform the concluding bow. The memorial is presented in the proper order.

Should no separate bowing be required, this procedure need not be strictly observed. The Daoist assembly gathers in the Master’s Hall. The High Priest offers incense. The Master of Rites escorts the *Zhai* Official to offer incense and bow three times before returning to their position. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Jade Clarity Heavenly Worthy of Purging Filth*. The Lector recites the *Purging Filth Mantra* and purifies the path with sprinkled water. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Golden Perfected Heavenly Worthy of Expounding the Teachings*. Two officials bearing the memorial table advance to receive it. The Attendant at the Censer chants the *Hymn of Huaxia*, and the assembly proceeds to welcome the memorial together, advancing to the site of its offering.

The High Priest offers incense, and the Master of Rites escorts the *Zhai* Official to offer incense and bow three times. Next, the Keeper of the Bell chants the *Step-in-Emptiness Ritual*, and a Dharma Master performs the three-fold offering of the memorial. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Three-Offering Ritual*, and the *Petition of Repentance* is recited. The assembly is then led to the altar’s front, where the High Priest stands in order at the *Earth Gate*. The High Priest purifies with sprinkled water and transforms through spirit-step and Dipper-walking. The High Priest wields the sword and proceeds to the *Heavenly Gate*. Facing southeast, the Announcer follows the High Priest to the *Heavenly Gate* and recites the *Boundary-Sealing Mantra*. The Attendants, following the directions, burn the *Boundary-Sealing Talismans*, while the High Priest and Announcer proceed. In sequence, they reach the *Heavenly Gate*, *Earth Gate*, *Human Gate*, and *Ghost Path*, where they sprinkle water, burn talismans, and recite mantras. Returning to their positions in order, the Keeper of the Bell chants the *Hymn of the Dao*. The Attendant at the Censer chants the *Hymn of Huaxia*, and the assembly circumambulates while offering incense. The High Priest approaches the *Cave Table* to offer incense thrice, then returns to position. Kneeling before the censer, they bow three times. The Attendants present the memorial for transmission. The High Priest performs the four-directional heart-bow with reverent focus. The High Priest then returns the memorial to the Attendants, who place it upon the table.

The Lector chants, and all pay homage to their masters and cultivate mindfulness as prescribed. The High Priest recites the *Guardian Spirit Mantra*. The Lector chants, and the *Dharma Drum* is struck twenty-four times. The High Priest opens the censer, and the Lector chants again as the *Dharma Drum* resounds. The High Priest invokes the officials, and the Lector chants, announcing their dharma ranks. The High Priest declares their roles and invokes the sagely presence into the ritual. The Announcer approaches the High Priest, kneels to receive the duplicate text, and proceeds before the altar to recite the memorial. The High Priest, holding the memorial, bows to reveal its intent. Upon completion of the recitation, the memorial is sealed. The High Priest then holds the memorial and kneels to dispatch the officials. The memorial is carried to the censer for the *Black Memorial* rite. The High Priest recites the *Five-Colored Smoke Mantra*, each invocation followed by a response, summoning the generals, issuing the mandate, and the assembly welcomes the memorial for burning. The High Priest mobilizes spirit, performs the *Ninefold Numinous Dipper Rite*, and prostrates. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Hymn of Burning the Memorial* and the *Great Demon-Subduing Mantra of the Five Emperors*. The Daoist assembly stands in attendance as the High Priest rises from prostration to report. Next, the *Harmonious Treasure Memorial* is proclaimed thrice. The Keeper of the Bell chants as they step upon the *Cloud Dipper*.

The High Priest receives the officials. If the memorial rite precedes the altar’s establishment, the *Twelve Talismans of the Void Sovereign* are here bestowed. If the altar’s establishment precedes the memorial rite, the *Talismans of Salvation* are also bestowed at this time. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Jade Talisman Heavenly Worthy of Pardoning Sins*, and the High Priest kneels to petition for the talismans while the *Petition of Repentance* is recited. The High Priest recites the *Talisman Blessing Mantra*, and the Keeper of the Bell chants the *Talisman Dispatch Mantra*. Next, the *Twelve Vows* are recited. The Lector chants the *Cultivation of Spirit and Incense Offering*. The High Priest returns to the censer. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Hymn of Exiting the Hall*, followed by the *Hymn of the Preceding Rites*. The Announcer delivers the *Dedication*, and the Attendant at the Censer leads the assembly back to the Master’s Hall. The Keeper of the Bell chants the *Heavenly Worthy of the Dao, the Scriptures, the Masters, and the Treasures*, then the *Hymn of Taking Refuge in the Orthodox Dao*. The Master of Rites escorts the *Zhai* Official to offer incense and bow three times. Next, the *Memorial Rite Concluded* is chanted, and all officials return to their positions. The officials bow in order.
