*Lingbao Jade Canon*, Scroll Seventeen Concludes
*Lingbao Jade Canon*, Scroll Eighteen: *Flying to the Divine Gate to Petition the Emperor*
*The Nine Numinous Flying Pace Petition Method*

According to the transmission of the Supreme Perfected of the Southern Culmen, Controller of Destinies, Lady Wei of the Orthodox Origin: during the Jin dynasty, the Female Official Libationer and Orthodox Unity Celestial Master, Lord Zhang, received *The Great Clarity Petitioning the Offices Rites* and the *Entering the Retreat Method*. Moreover, since the Han era, the matters of the One Thousand Two Hundred Offices have been transmitted in correspondence, and it is fitting to uphold and employ them. Additionally, the Orthodox Unity Petition Regulations recorded in the Jade Casket, the Red Pine Treasure Register, the Jade Almanac, and the inner and outer talismanic contracts serve as established methods. After Master Du of the Broad Accomplishment of the Tang dynasty compiled and arranged the *Proclamation of Compassion Petition Texts*, these were scattered and lost due to warfare, and complete versions are rare. Now, when petitions are to be presented, there is no fixed format. Recently, due to the mediocrity and recklessness of later scholars, arbitrary additions and omissions have been made, rendering them unfit for use. Furthermore, the offices and ranks are disordered, the formats are inauthentic, the petitions fail to reach their intended destination, and the acts of reverence do not accord with the profound principles. This is not due to the lack of sincerity in the fasting officials’ hearts but rather to the extreme difficulty of obtaining worthy adepts. If petitions are presented carelessly, it is as if casting them into the void, inviting reprimands and punishments—truly lamentable and grievous.

Therefore, after profound reflection and hidden inquiry, consulting the numinous texts, eliminating the superfluous and extracting the essential, simplifying and returning to the source, I have compiled and arranged these writings to assist the *Five Origins Jade Registers* in transforming and praising, instructing and teaching the learners of the true, and aiding both the living and the deceased. The purport of the *Nine Numinous* method is to be received separately with the true rites. Such matters as the *Great Clarity Entering the Retreat Oral Petition* are not to be fathomed by ordinary talents. Their forms communicate with the true and reach the numinous, their spirits ascend the jade steps, and even the immortal officials may not necessarily adhere to them. Yet how can the Three Caverns’ Daoists, libationers, and disciples neglect these profound and secret mysteries? Upon reading the texts, one should awaken in heart and mind and carefully attend to them. Take care not to leak them lightly. Those who receive and transmit them must petition the Three Heavens, offering nine pairs of gold rings and ninety feet of azure silk, swearing an oath before bestowing them. They may not be transmitted more than three times in a lifetime. Those who violate this will suffer death and the destruction of their families—beware!

**Thirty Articles of the Three Caverns’ Mysterious Regulations**

When a master presents a petition on behalf of the common people, the documents must not be left scattered or delayed among mortals. All should be collected and recorded, and all matters within a year should be addressed. Daoist followers must not record them.

Petition cases should be one foot and five inches long, one foot wide, and eight inches high, with curved legs, and made of cypress wood.

Petition caskets should be one foot and two inches long, four inches square, with an additional inch in intercalary months. The measurement should be based on the middle joint of the master’s middle finger; glue must not be used. The casket should have an opening at the bottom.

For presenting petitions, separate incense and fire must be used; one must not use fire or ashes from the kitchen hearth.

For the method of presenting petitions of gratitude and apology, face north, with all household members, young and old, loosening their hair and crossing their hands to request the petition.

Curved-leg cases should be used for presenting petitions. Other stools are unsuitable, as they prevent the petitions from being spiritually received.

Petition caskets should be sealed with an imprint and labeled according to the method. Others are not suitable for presentation.

During the presentation of petitions, those in the household of the offering official must not create disorder with loud voices, nor should chickens or dogs startle and bark, lest the spirit-*qi* be unsettled and the petition fail to ascend.

When a master presents a petition on behalf of an offering official, there should be ritual tokens and merit offerings of delicate items. It is hoped that illnesses will diminish and cease, and that entanglements and obstacles will be resolved. On the day of receiving grace, one may accept ritual tokens and alms.

Those who violate this will be treated as thieves and punished according to the six penal codes, liable for three thousand tiles and bricks.

When a master officiates in presenting petitions to save the sick or deliver the common people from calamity, if people urgently seek help for grave illnesses and the master remains at home under false pretenses or fails to attend to the emergency, the offender will suffer ten days of illness as punishment.

Incense stands should have a base, be two feet and four inches long, one foot and six inches wide, and two feet and four inches high, sufficient to support the petition case.

The paper for writing petitions must be pure and clean, without holes, tears, or uneven edges, and should not have fewer than three lines remaining at the end. If insufficient, use whole sheets. Otherwise, desist.

The small characters on the petition should be one inch and two fen long, with four fen extending beyond; otherwise, they are unsuitable. Small characters refer to the Great Clarity precinct.

When presenting petitions for the chief transgressions of offering officials or for private and secret matters, one may petition in the retreat, burning the petition words directly. The matters must not be publicly declared or disclosed to others. Revealing them to the netherworld authorities is a grave offense.

For petitions, whether large or small, exposed or indoor, all should be retained for three days. The case must not be immediately dismantled, the seat removed, or the petition hastily burned. If in doubt, burn it.

When presenting petitions in the retreat, the superior position faces east. If there are matters to be exposed, all face north.

On the Three Assembly Days and Community Days, one must not present routine petitions or memorials. For urgent matters, the three-eight-day solar apologies are not prohibited.

From three days before to three days after the Winter Solstice, one must not present routine documents or petition writings. Urgent matters are not prohibited.

On the days of *wuxu* and *wuchen*, one must not rashly enter the retreat. If it is the fifteenth day of the month or a Three Assembly Day, one must not perform morning audiences. The Three Assemblies have separate petitions for changing the day; the words and sections for Community Days are suitable for presentation but not for the Assemblies.

On the three days of the Three Assemblies, one should report merits. If there are matters on those days preventing presentation, one may present them afterward without omission.

When register initiates present petitions themselves, they may orally state what they wish to say.

When receiving grace, one must personally declare one’s merits and virtues, which are then conveyed to the original master for retention. The original master’s distant conveyance is for the sake of proximity. If a master presenting a petition consumes mutton or wine, their foul breath entering the retreat will forfeit three thousand merits. When the officers and soldiers return to the Heavenly Bureau, if your petitions are empty for a hundred days, the throne will not hear them. One must not drink wine in the home of the sick, lest a hundred ghosts hide within the person’s body. If the illness is not cured after healing rites, the petition will not be received. When a master presenting a petition encounters illness, they must save and sustain the person’s life. If one harbors prior enmity and wishes death upon another, the misfortune will rebound upon oneself.

When disciples present petitions on behalf of their master, they should begin by stating on this day: "Your servant, so-and-so, the master I follow." If, while a disciple presents a petition for their master, there is urgent illness in the household, they must withdraw and request leave, not stopping at mere verbal acknowledgment. If there is no urgent illness, this is unnecessary.

When writing petitions, use clean brushes and inkstones, and hold the petition with the petition table as part of the ritual; only then may it be prepared. Do not drape the petition over one’s body or place it on a bed, lest the petition go unheard and merit be lost through labor and error.

For the rites of a *jiao* official presenting a petition, one must burn incense, enter the fasting chamber, bow, and request permission to present one’s case. One must not rashly carry the petition into the retreat without proper announcement, as this is like casting it into water.

For the method of presenting the *Luxing* Petition to the Supreme, one must burn incense, enter the retreat, and request the incense officials and messengers to bring the incense burner into the courtyard. One must not rashly enter the retreat to retrieve it, as this fails to properly address the Perfected Officials. If one merely carries the incense burner out while in the retreat, there will be no attendants or guards, demonic spirits will interfere with the petition, the myriad spirits will be wearied, and the paper and ink will be wasted, for there is no proper rite of invitation.

When presenting the *Luxing* Petition, there must be lamps, each with a dipper, and each dipper must have its *kuigang*. When the *gang* intersect, one must be cautious of the *gang*. Do not break the stars by misaligning them, and do not easily instruct others in this; beginners must be cautious.

When *jiao* officials face the petition, they must all face north. If there is urgent illness, they must go on foot, with hair unbound and hands clasped. If there is no such urgency, this is unnecessary.

The Mysterious Capital has its palaces and bureaus, each with its own overseers.

When Daoist petitions are submitted, if they reach the celestial audience but contain errors, deviations, or losses of the true Dao, with disordered sequence or misalignments that violate heavenly statutes, they will be rejected by the celestial bureaus, the matters will fail to reach the throne, and the unknowing petitioner will vainly entrust their hopes, believing the petition has been received. When the matter fails, they will claim the Dao is without efficacy, never attributing the fault to the Daoist—how grievous this is. If the petition conforms to the statutes and commits no transgressions, all ailments treated will be cured, and all lives saved will be preserved.

**Petition Writing Regulations**
The height of petition paper should measure one *chi* and nine *fen*, or, by the smaller standard, one *chi* and two *cun*, or one *chi* and four *cun*. Each sheet should have twelve lines, or some say nine lines, with seventeen characters per line. Alternatively, one line may span the entire width. Each line should be one *cun* and two *fen* wide, or two *cun* and four *fen*. In the *Zhengyi* method, leave an eight-character indentation. In the *Taixuan Du* protocol, the first line of the official title should be indented by one character, approximately two lines in length. Ancient methods did not specify indentation, or allowed three lines, aligning with the yang number of the Three Powers.

The first line should conclude the ritual title, followed by "prostrating twice and respectfully submitting," with an eight-*fen* indentation above and a continuous line of "ant-walk" script below. The ritual title should be one character higher than the "respectfully submitting" line. Ensure the text aligns precisely, with the lower section’s language concise and the name written in a single unbroken character—no splitting allowed, as in cases like "so-and-so, née Ji." The character *chen* (臣) must not begin a line, nor *gui* (鬼) head one. Avoid placing characters denoting life or death in prominent positions. Terms like *hunpo* (魂魄) or references to death must be avoided at the start of lines.

One *cun* below "prostrating twice," write "to be heard," and for the concluding line, begin a new row. The *Xiuzhen Zhiyao* follows this, while Cai Zhixu’s ritual places the characters *gaobao* (告報) below "to be heard." After "to be heard," leave three lines blank before writing the petitioner’s surname. After the surname, leave another three lines blank before writing the *Taiqing* rank. Following this, leave three more lines blank before writing "Minister [Name], subject of the Great Year," aligning with the "Great Year" line. Two *cun* and four *fen* below "respectfully submitting," begin writing. The "Great Year" line should be evenly spaced to reach the end of the row. Adjust the margins at the start and end of the paper, adding a sheet if too short.

The *Taiqing* rank consists of fifty-six characters, written in compact, fine script. The upper section measures three *cun* and six *fen*, the middle four *cun* and five *fen*, and the lower five *cun*, not exceeding these dimensions. This follows the ancient statutes of Master Red Pine. For forty-eight characters, write them in three *cun*. In the *Xiuzhen Zhiyao*, omit the four characters *Jinque Qibao* (金闕七寶), resulting in fifty-four characters. Since discrepancies exist, careful verification is required.

Petitions must not be written across days, and "Your Majesty" must not be filled in across different times. Ancient methods required filling in *Taiqing* without delay. The characters *Bixia* (陛下) should be written finely in a single line, like the *Taiqing* rank. Some suggest writing only these two characters finely, but *Bixia* is a term of respect and should not be split. Writing them separately may appear unstable. Neither the *Wulian Shengshi Jing*’s yellow-silk petition method nor the Zhang-Du *Eryi* texts address this. Thus, write them finely in a single line.

**Heart Petition Format**
The statutes state: Heart petitions are only for submitting matters and must not be verbose; the words must convey the intent directly. For submitting to the *Xuwu Ziran Yuque* method, use yellow silk measuring one *chi* and two *cun* in length and three *cun* and six *fen* in height, written densely in fine cinnabar script. Leave a three-*fen* margin above and one *fen* below, with no fixed number of lines. Leave blank space at the start of the petition for the *Huangshen* seal and at the end for the *Yuezhang* seal. Seal it with a leak-proof closure, not a square box. During prostration, visualize the process according to the *Chaoyuan* method.

For the first prostration, hold the petition and bow. For the second, present the petition and orally state its intent. For the third, visualize the Celestial Worthy’s disposition of the matter. When burning, use the *Lingbao* Heart Mantra in a large incense burner. Such petitions are submitted urgently and receive a response within an hour. Those without merit may not submit them.

"On the [day] of [month] in the [year], after fasting and purification, with reverence and awe, prostrating twice, I respectfully submit: Your servant, based on the matter at hand, humbly invokes the Left and Right Dragon-Tiger Lords, the Incense-Bearing Golden Youth, the Jade Maiden Transmitters, the Incense Official Envoys, the Three *Qi* Orthodox Spirits, the *Qi*-Hastening Merit Officers, and the Flying Petition Attendants."

**Alternative Format**
The statutes state: Heart petitions follow the *Taiqing* format, with a length of five *cun* and six *fen* and a height of three *cun* and two *fen*. Using the middle joint of the middle finger as a measure, each line contains seventeen characters, and each sheet must not exceed twelve lines. For *Yuqing* and *Shangqing*, use yellow silk with cinnabar script; for *Taiqing*, use ink, though urgent matters may be written in cinnabar, all in three grades.

*Yuqing* uses the *Feixuan Sanqi Yuzhang* seal; *Shangqing* uses the *Taishang Santian* seal, the *Jiuling Feibu* seal, and the *Taiqing* seal; *Taiqing* uses the *Huangshen Yuezhang* seal. Regardless of urgency, seal it securely without a square box. Such petitions receive a response within moments.

**Petition Format**

The humble official, [Your] Servant [Name], with utmost reverence and trepidation, prostrates and bows twice to submit this memorial.

Your servant, kneeling in accordance with the rites, respectfully presents an urgent *Feixuan Sanqi* Heart Petition, to be delivered to the Celestial Bureau of [specific] Heaven of the Three Heavens, humbly petitioning for the invocation of [specific deities, e.g., *Jiayi*]. Furthermore, your servant respectfully invokes the following attendants:

The Direct Envoys of the Two Offices, the *Zhengyi* Merit Registrars, the Left and Right Official Messengers, the *Yin-Yang* Divine Central Clerks, the *Keche* Scarlet Talisman Clerks, the *Gangfeng* Courier Riders, the Post-Horse Petition Bearers, the *Feilong* Interpreting Clerks, the Jade Lads and Maidens of the Five Thearchs, the Flying Heavenly Divine Kings of the Five Thearchs, the Thirty-Two Heavenly Memorial-Submitting Clerks, the Ten Heavenly Jade Maidens of Reception, the Three-Five Merit Registrars, the Incense-Attending Golden Lads, the *Chuanyan* Jade Clerks, the Jade Thearch’s Direct Envoys, and the Direct-Day Incense Officials—each dispatched in pairs.

Your servant, on behalf of disciple [Name], submits this petition to the Celestial Bureau of [specific] Heaven, awaiting the divine response. After your servant’s report is received, it shall be transmitted through the Three Ranks of the Grand Year [Name].

**Seal Protocol for *Zhengyi* Petitions**
The statutes state: The *Zhengyi* Dao of the *Taiqing* was transmitted by the Supreme Sage of the Mysterious Origin to the Celestial Master of the Orthodox Unity. For the rite of petitioning, the *Nine Elder Immortals of the Xian Du* seal is employed, as the Eight Elders of the *Taiqing* revere the Supreme Venerable as their master. Thus, disciples submit their memorials to their master, hence the use of the *Nine Elder Immortals of the Xian Du* seal.

Additionally, twelve smaller seals are used, from the *Tai Xuan Du* to the Grand Year, all to be impressed on the reverse. Some traditions include a border following the seal format, while others omit the border, resembling a talisman. This should be determined by careful consideration.

**Petitions of the *Dongzhen***

**Petitions of the *Dongzhen***

The statutes state: The *Dongzhen* rank pertains to the Dao of the *Yuqing*. It emerged during the Yonghe era of the Jin dynasty, transmitted by the Seven Perfected—Three Mao, Two Xu, Yang, and Guo—without a fixed format for memorials and petitions.

**Seal Format for *Dongxuan* Petitions**

The statutes state: The *Dongxuan* Dao is the teaching of the *Lingbao*. Its doctrines existed as early as the era of the Three Sovereigns. Originally, there was no fixed format for petitions, as seen in the *Scripture of the Five Refinements for Animating the Corpse* and the *Original Conduct of the Five Elders*, differing from the methods of standard petitions. When performing *Dongxuan* rites, the petition should have blank space before and after, with talismans inscribed according to the prescribed form. Only the *Tongzhang* seal is applied above the date. Since the *Yuchen* is a disciple of the Celestial Worthy of Primordial Beginning, this seal serves to convey sincerity to the ancestral master. Those not ordained in this register may not presumptuously use its seal script. The *Shenxiao* register also employs it. Some claim this seal belongs to the *Yuqing* and the *Dongzhen* department, unaware that before the rise of the *Shenxiao* teachings, *Dongxuan* petition methods from before the Five Dynasties all used this seal. The *Tongzhang* seal is in fact the *Great Charter for Ascending to Heaven*, merely omitting its lower text. The living use it as proof for ascending petitions into the celestial courts. When bestowed upon the deceased, it includes summons for the soul and related matters. The *Great Charter for Ascending to Heaven* has, from ancient times to the present, clearly belonged to the *Dongxuan* department—how could it be ascribed to the *Dongzhen*? The current use of the *Tongzhang* seal in *Dongxuan* petitions follows the original statutes of the *Lingbao*. If another seal is substituted where this one should be used, it must be reviewed by the Three Officials.

**Format for Yellow Silk and Vermilion Petitions**

The statutes state: Use twelve feet of yellow silk, backed with light yellow silk and cut to a height of one foot two inches. Each line contains twenty-four characters, with a line width of one inch two *fen*, or nine *fen* as a standard. If following ancient methods, one line measures two inches four *fen*, but this may be impractical for lengthy texts; adjust the number of lines according to the word count. Since the petition is called *huangsu* ("yellow silk"), raw yellow silk should be used. Master Tian, finding it too soft for handling, recommended backing it with thin paper for ease, then inscribing in vermilion. The dimensions, whether height or width, generally follow the petition format. Seal it in a round fold, with an inner and outer square envelope, both made of yellow silk. The outermost layer bears the supplicant’s surname in plain script. The fifth northern panel holds the supplicant’s surname, aligned with the Grand Year. The sixth northern panel contains the *Taiqing* forty-eight characters, written in three-inch script. The seventh northern panel holds the year, month, day, and hour, followed by "respectfully submitted from [such-and-such] prefecture, village, and hamlet." The eighth panel leaves three blank panels for the Three Masters’ spiritual praise; if insufficient, use additional paper to fill them. The ninth panel marks the petition’s boundaries with eight-part regular script on the top margin, while the central margin is divided according to the method of measurement. The tenth panel follows the above method for petition formatting, without arbitrary margin adjustments.

The decree states: Daoists of the *Zhengyi* tradition must adhere to the ten regulations above when inscribing petitions. No arbitrary margin adjustments or personal innovations are permitted, lest they mislead later learners. Violators who devise their own methods shall be judged under the five penalties of the *Zhengyi* Daoist code. The fifth penalty entails repairing thatched roofs with three thousand bundles of straw.

11. When placing the petition, use a cloth beneath it to prevent the paper from touching the bed. The paper must also conform to the proper method; avoid letting clothing brush against it. Inscribe the petition with care.
12. Ink, brush, paper, and inkstone must be kept pure; no defilement or mixed use is allowed.
13. When grinding ink for the petition, rotate the inkstick forty-nine times to the left and right, then stop.
14. When dipping the brush in ink, turn it seven times to the left and right; do not hold the brush in the mouth.
15. While inscribing the petition, do not engage in idle conversation or extraneous speech, lest it manifest in the text.
16. The water in the inkstone should be clear and settled.
17. Do not dip the brush in water and drip it onto the inkstone.
18. While inscribing the petition, keep the mouth closed; no eating or drinking is permitted.
19. Do not inscribe a petition while the body is defiled.
20. Select a clean hand towel and wash the hands before proceeding.
21. Do not allow errors or incomplete characters in the petition; stop if corrections are needed.
22. Ensure the petition paper is not torn or marred by stray brushstrokes.
23. Do not let the petition paper fall to the ground, rendering it unusable.
24. Do not inscribe the petition while recording matters of food, meat, or defilement.
25. Do not inscribe the petition while recording defiled or impure matters.

The decree states: The fifteen regulations above govern the preparation of petitions. Daoists must adhere to these statutes. Those who violate or disregard them shall be judged under the three penalties of the *Zhengyi* Daoist code. The three penalties entail sweeping roads and bridges for thirty days.

26. When inscribing a petition, attire must be neat; no exposure of the body is permitted.
27. When inscribing a petition, assume a reverent posture; no slouching or squatting is allowed.
28. After inscribing the petition, read it silently once to check for errors.
29. For omitted characters, correct them with white ink and realgar.
30. Do not rest the hand on the table while inscribing.
31. Do not allow others to secretly read the petition.
32. Do not predate the *Taiqing* day and hour on the petition; fill them in at the time of submission.
33. When a Daoist inscribes small characters in a petition, the officiant should request it with a sash tied.
34. When the officiant requests the petition, perform three bows, three prostrations, and three rises—nine acts in total.
35. When the officiant bows before the petition, conclude with a personal prayer, expressing wishes according to the heart, such as seeking swift recovery from illness.
36. After the Daoist concludes the petition, the officiant offers thanks, bowing and prostrating as before.
37. If the officiant suffers from illness or misfortune, urgently summon the master. Before the master, perform thirty-two bows and prostrations each.

38. After the officiant concludes the bowing, stand before the Daoist and state the urgent matters of illness or other pressing concerns—do not sit while speaking.

39. When the master arrives at the officiant’s home, all members of the household, young and old, must bow and prostrate; none may remain at ease.

40. When the officiant requests the master to submit a petition, present the offering of incense and paper with sincerity—do not make requests directly to the master.

41. When the master arrives at the officiant’s home, they must devote full attention to preparing the petition, without negligence or delay.

42. If the officiant suffers from severe illness, follow the prescribed rites and make vows according to their means, whether rich or poor.

43. If the officiant faces grave misfortune, present the offering of sincerity and, trusting in the grace received, deliver it promptly on the same day—do not delay.

44. The master must align with the officiant’s intentions, adhering to the prescribed vows, and may not alter them by treating light matters as grave.

45. When the master submits the petition, it must be clear and pure, free from disorder, defilement, or erroneous words.

The above twenty articles, if violated or mistaken, result in disrespect from the petitioner and irreverence from the master, causing the petition to fail, illnesses to remain uncured, and disasters to go unaverted. Both the host and the master shall be subject to the three penal statutes.

The three penalties entail sweeping roads and repairing bridges for thirty days.

The preceding forty-five articles are derived from the *Orthodox Petition Documents: Regulations Under the Section on Petition Rites*. *Orthodox Petition Documents: Ritual Standards*.

When the master writes petitions or memorials, he must first purify himself through fasting and ablutions, rinse his mouth, wash his hands and face, adjust his robes and cap, enter the oratory, face the Heavenly Gate to arrange his seat, burn incense, click his teeth, swallow his saliva, and clear his mind of all extraneous thoughts. He then spreads a clean cloth upon the table and visualizes the Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, and Black Tortoise guarding the four directions. Next, he burns incense, grinds ink with forty-nine circular motions, and passes the brush through the incense smoke. He recites the incantation:

*"Swift and divine brush, let this sacred writing reach its destination.
May this servant attain long life and present his petition to the Jade Clarity.
May all evil vanish and demonic forces be severed.
Those who violate this petition shall be punished by the Northern Emperor.
Hasten, as decreed by the statutes!"*

With the brush in hand, he offers incense and recites:

*"I invoke the Heavenly Masters, the Lineage Masters, the Female Masters and Ladies, the Scripture Masters, the Register Masters, the Merit Officers, and the Generals and Divine Soldiers.
Attend me now as I write this petition on behalf of [name], ensuring it ascends without delay or error.
Hasten, as decreed by the statutes!"*

He then begins writing, reciting the preceding regulations and statutes with utmost sincerity. He must not speak to others and should hold his breath. He may not set down the brush until the writing is complete, nor allow any omissions, smudges, or corrections—if an error occurs, he must replace the paper. No outsiders, chickens, or dogs may enter the room, and he must not raise his voice while writing. He may not leave his seat until the reading is finished, nor allow the incense smoke to extinguish. When writing the characters "陛下" (Your Majesty) in the *Taiqing* petition, he leaves them blank and fills them in only during the prostration. The scribe must be meticulous, ensuring no strokes are missing or broken, and must not alter the text arbitrarily. The intent of the fast must be coherent, without interruption. Upon completion, the petition must not be left in an impure place but placed before the master. While writing, the Divine Officers, Merit Officers, and Twelve Celestial Scribes oversee the process, recording all merits and transgressions without omission. The gravity of these prohibitions and solemnities must not be transgressed.

**Sealing the Petition: Regulations**
When presenting a petition, the host must don formal attire and request the document in accordance with the *Orthodox Petition Documents: Regulations*. As the master approaches the altar and completes the ritual departure of the officials, he retrieves the petition. After writing it for presentation to the Supreme Emperor, he takes the Dragon Blade to open the case, unfolds the petition upon the table, and recites it. He then displays it upon the *Taiqing* steps, aligning it with the center of the Supreme Emperor’s presence. The Dragon Blade is placed before the *Taiqing*’s "陛下," with the Golden Fish and Jade Wild Goose positioned to its left and right, and the new brush, cinnabar ink, and inkstone placed before it. Once arranged, he visualizes the Divine Scribes and Officers examining the text. After this, he fills in the characters "陛下," tightly rolls the petition over the incense, and encases it in a round seal. The round seal is made from a full sheet of paper, placed within a square inner case. This is then enclosed in a wooden case, bound with three knots of green silk, the ends of which are submerged in a wax pool and sealed with paper stamped with the *Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital* seal. Alternatively, glue may be used instead of wax. The outer layer is wrapped in blue paper, then sealed in a yellow silk pouch, with the character "封" (Seal) written on the upper corner. The petition is then wrapped in a yellow silk cloth, placed upon the table, and bowed to before being burned in the petition furnace. The master prostrates before the altar, following the prescribed steps for presenting the petition.

**Writing Talismans: Method**
The Mysterious Master said: The method of presenting petitions was transmitted by the August Dao Lord of the Luminous Mystery, who received it from the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy. Through silent audience with the Three Heavens, he orally presented the memorials of supplication—this is not something ordinary people may hear. Only those whose names are recorded in the Three Heavens, who hold the rank of Perfected, and who enter and leave the Golden Gates may practice this. Without the rank of First-Rank Immortal Official, one may not perform the Great Rites of the Numinous Treasure, nor present petitions or memorials. The world of the *Gangfeng* (Celestial Winds) cannot be pierced without the radiant wisdom of the Numinous Treasure. The method requires selecting an *gengzi* day when the sky is clear. Prepare an incense table facing the Heavenly Gate, form the Mudra of the Supreme Emperor with both hands, and transform one’s spirit into the likeness of a Perfected. First, step through the Five Phases to transcend the *Gangfeng*, then use yellow silk inscribed with a talisman—ground from realgar, orpiment, and cinnabar—to place within one’s cap and shoes. Write and ingest talismans for ablution and purification. When writing talismans, hold the brush, click the teeth, and visualize the Primordial Qi of the Mysterious Origin descending into the brush. Upon completion, place the talismans in the oratory alongside the petitions and seals, all arranged before the sacred presence. Use them in accordance with the method when the time comes. First, draft the diagrams for the petitions, burn incense daily, recite the incantations, and visualize them in accordance with the *Chaoyuan* method until they are familiar.

**First Realm: The Desire Realm**
The celestial patterns of the Purple Tenuity Starry Heaven—gazing upward, one beholds the constellations of the celestial expanse. Its gate is called the *Yangjing* Heavenly Gate. The divine talisman belongs to General Tang, granted the name *Lingjun* (Numinous Lord) and the style *Dongchang*. He oversees the submission of petitions and memorials to the First Heavenly Gate. His divine officers include *Muxuji*, *Tianfuying* (Merit Officer), the youth *Yang Bohua*, and *Danyuanhui* (Guide of the Cinnabar Radiance)—all holding positions among the Heavenly Officials. Only General Tang guards his post for ten thousand years; the others serve for ten thousand years before replacement. The *Taiyi Scripture* states: they are replaced once per kalpa.

**Second Realm: The Form Realm**
The Jade Dawn Heaven of the Purple Tenuity Enclosure—the jeweled realm of *Yuyu*, the seven-treasured Purple Tenuity Palace. Its gate is called the *Donghua* Heavenly Gate, and its deity is General Ge, granted the name *Linghou* (Numinous Marquis) and the style *Dongliang*. He oversees the submission of petitions and memorials to the Second Heavenly Gate. His divine generals include *Han Quanlin*, *Youjie* (Merit Officer of the Hidden Realm), the youth *Deng Fanghua*, and *Lingyuandao* (Three Generals of the Numinous Garden)—all appointed by the Supreme Emperor to guard their posts. Those with merit are replaced once per kalpa.

**Third Realm: The Formless Realm**
The Golden Gates of the *Liaoyang* Heaven and the *Zhengyang* Gate—this is the abode of the Supreme Emperor, the alternate realm where the Great Dao Lord of the Jade Dawn governs transformations. The *Taiyi Scripture* states: this is the transformed body of the Primordial Beginning, the Jade Emperor Supreme.

The Jade Dawn is also a transformed body of the Primordial Beginning. Thus, the three lofty realms of the Highest Mornings are all the Primordial Beginning’s singular body divided into three. Therefore, the wondrous transformations of the Dao’s unfolding and the myriad changes of its responsive manifestations are beyond the comprehension of all human and heavenly perfected beings—how could the human mind fully fathom them?

The Heavenly Gate General, Zhou General, is granted the name *Lingwu* (Numinous Martial) and the style *Dongjing* by the Supreme Emperor. He oversees the submission of petitions and memorials from the Three Heavenly Gates below, known as the Purple Tenuity Prefecture. His divine generals include *Li Jiqing*, the Merit Officer *Dongqingchen*, the youth *Cao Jinghua*, and *Ruan Ziqing*, who is charged with the Supreme Emperor’s talismanic decrees and the transmission of memorials. Those with merit are replaced once every ten thousand kalpas.

**First Heavenly Gate:** *Celestial Numinous Talismanic Contract*
**Second Heavenly Gate:** *Jade Radiance Talismanic Contract*
**Third Heavenly Gate:** *Primordial Spirit Talismanic Contract*

These Three Heavenly Contracts must be carved and worn. For kings, they are made of metal or stone; for Daoist priests, they are made of wood. They are stored in a crimson pouch, which is tied to the left elbow, and also affixed to the memorials. Daoist priests of the Orthodox Unity Alliance and those who receive the registers of the *Lu* disciples, or who present memorials to pray for the nation’s well-being, must all wear the Three Heavenly Talismanic Contracts. In preparation, one should visualize and swallow the Five Spirit Talismans, along with the *Hundred Spirits Decoction*, bathe, enter the chamber, face east, and recite the *Lingbao Shangqing* incantation. Seven days prior, one must submit a petition to the Three Heavens, invoking the divine generals and officials to present the memorial. Only then may one enter the precincts of the Three Heavenly Gates. At the appointed time, the memorial is prostrated, and a response is received.

**Great Clarity Title:**
The Supreme, Primordial, Peerless, Three Heavens, Boundless, Great Dao, Most High Lord Lao, Most High Venerable Celestial Emperor Lord, Nine Elders of the Immortal Capital, Nine Qi Venerable, Myriad Layers of Dao Qi, Twelve Hundred Official Lords of the Great Clarity, at the Golden Gates and Jade Steps of the Great Clarity.

**Highest Clarity Title:**
Jade Dawn Dao Realm, Yuanyu Heavenly Palace, Primordial August, Most Sagely, Thirty-Two Heavens, Chaos Primordial Ancestor, Nine Heavens Celestial Emperor, Ancestral Master, Most High Jade Dawn Great Dao Lord, Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy, at the Golden Gates and Jade Steps of the Highest Clarity.

**Jade Clarity Title:**
Supreme Great Luo Heaven, Clear Tenuity Palace, Void Origin, Natural, Mysterious Vault, Most Sagely, Ancestor of Myriad Dao, Five Elders Celestial Emperor, Ancestral Master, Golden Gates Void Sovereign Supreme Emperor, Primordial Heavenly Worthy, at the Golden Gates and Jade Steps of the Jade Clarity.

**Three Clarities Collective Title:**
Most High Primordial Form, Nameless, Void, Natural, Boundless Great Dao, Perfect Truth, Supreme Mysterious Worthy, at the Golden Gates and Seven Treasures Jade Steps.

**Memorial Envelope and Seal Cover Formats:**
- **Round Seal Format:** Use a full sheet of paper; folding is not permitted.
- **Inner Square Envelope Format:** Wooden envelope.

Use cypress or catalpa wood, measuring one foot and two inches in length and four inches in width; in a leap year, add one inch. The measurement should be based on the middle joint of the presiding master’s middle finger. Do not use glue, and the bottom of the envelope should be openable.

The base of the memorial envelope consists of one board divided into upper, middle, and lower sections. Within the wooden envelope, three nested envelopes are required:
- The outermost (third) envelope: white
- The middle (second) envelope: yellow
- The innermost (first) envelope: blue-green

**Memorial Table Format:**
The memorial table should be made of cypress or catalpa wood, standing one foot and two inches in height, one foot and eight inches in length, and one foot and two inches in width. Each side should have six legs, totaling twelve. In a leap month, add one leg. The tabletop should be carved with the seven stars of the Northern Dipper.

**Ritual of Purification Before Memorial Submission:**
Submitting memorials for state or populace is not a matter to be undertaken lightly. One must first regulate body and mind, ensuring spirit and qi are harmonized and settled. Bathe for seven days, ingest the Five Spirit Talismans, and recite the Five Spirit Incantations. For seven days, ingest the Great Peace Talisman, and for another seven, the Spirit-Communing Talisman.

On the day of the Beginning of Summer, fell a jujube tree and craft an effigy of the Cinnabar Prime Lord, shaped like a perfected person, three inches in height and seven *fen* in width. Enter seclusion together with it for forty-nine days of practice. Then ingest the Heart Memorial Talisman to ensure the sincere intent is conveyed, aligning with the celestial mind so that primordial qi naturally ascends.

**Bathing Decoction:**
- Eight ounces of peach bark
- One ounce of frankincense
- One ounce of bamboo leaves
- One ounce of cogon grass
- Four ounces of cypress resin
- One ounce of costus root
- Five *qian* of benzoin

Grind the ingredients finely and steep in five *dou* and five *sheng* of fresh water. Each day at noon, ingest one Five Spirit Talisman and dissolve one Purification Talisman in the decoction. Visualize the Supreme Mystery Jade Maiden riding a dragon, spouting water into the chamber for bathing.

**Incantation:**
*"Heaven and Earth unfold in clarity,
The Four Great hold as constant.
Mysterious waters wash away defilement,
Banishing all inauspiciousness.
Twin youths guard the gate,
Seven Perfected protect the chamber.
Divine essence refines and cleanses,
Myriad qi harmonize in well-being.
Inner and outer attain integrity,
Preserving the Perfected August One."*

**Five Spirit Talismans:**
Dissolve in jujube and agarwood decoction using the Supreme Clarity method and the qi of the Five Directions.

**Incantation:**
*"Upper Prime Unity abides in the Muddy Pellet,
Middle Controller of Destiny rests in the Crimson Palace.
Lower Peach Vitality holds the register in the Palace of Life.
Prime Radiance Lad, White Prime Honored Spirit—
At the summons of the Jade Talisman,
The Five Spirits unite as one."*

**Purification Talisman:**
Recite the preceding bathing incantation while visualizing celestial nectar pouring over the body, immersing and refining it until golden light emanates. Write in cinnabar, using the Supreme Yin qi method, and ingest upon completing the bath.

**Great Peace Talisman:**
Dissolve in jujube and rush-pith decoction. Visualize the Cinnabar Prime Lord seated in the Crimson Palace, silently reciting the *Hidden Might of the Three Heavens* eighty-one times. Ascend the Three Pure Clouds to the Jade Hall, using the Jade Emperor’s method. Exhale qi over the body, then regulate breath and swallow saliva nine times.

**Five Spirit Incantation:**
*"Ingesting the spirit talismans,
Communing with the true numinous.
Hundred spirits merge in harmony,
Penetrating the depths of sincerity.
Six Jia spirits guard in profound stillness,
Five Phases’ primordial qi in boundless obscurity.
Before the chaos of beginning,
Myriad things were formless.
The true nature awakens,
Hearing sound, knowing names.
Heaven and Earth’s divine canon,
Called ‘Opening the Heart.’
Mysterious principle unfolds in enlightenment,
Ingesting brings great peace.
Attaining the natural,
Ascending the Purple Court.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by law!"*

**Ritual of Seclusion:**
The master enters seclusion, burns incense, and faces east. Visualize amidst five-colored clouds: Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, Dark Warrior, and Central Yellow. Above and around the head: sun, moon, thunder, seas, mountains, Six Jia, Six Ding, and the *shi* and *jiao* spirits within and without.

Next, concentrate the spirit to achieve profound stillness, severing all distractions. Inner and outer become luminously clear. Knock the teeth and refine saliva thirty-six times. Focus the mind on wondrous transformation, uniting the heart with the Great Void. A single thought connects upward to the Three Realms; all matters and principles respond to intent. Then ingest the talisman.

**Spirit-Communing Talisman:**
Write in cinnabar on yellow paper using the Jade Clarity method and the qi of the Heavenly Gate. Visualize jade qi ascending to the Three Realms, a single spirit illuminating the ten directions.

**Cinnabar Prime Lord Incantation:**
*"Spirit within the heart, Cinnabar Prime Lord,
Three inches tall, seven *fen* wide.
Clad in vermilion robes, girded in crimson skirts.
Wielding virtue and power, manifesting supreme numinosity.
Mastering transformation, penetrating the mysterious and true.
Dwell within the heart, never leave the body.
If urgent matters arise, hasten to report to me.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by the Purple Court Emperor!"*

Craft the Cinnabar Prime Lord as before, enter seclusion together, and the master ingests the Heart Memorial Talisman.

**Heart Memorial Talisman:**
Use the qi of the northwest and the Jade Clarity method. Create a small version, writing on paper colored according to the season: green in spring, red in summer, white in autumn, black in winter. Face the direction of the prevailing phase, burn with incense, hold the ashes on the tongue, and tilt the face upward to draw green qi from the east for nine breaths. Next, look upward to the sky and draw red light for three breaths. Then, prostrate to the earth and draw yellow qi for five breaths. Merge the three colors in the mouth, forming a radiant light like the sun. Swallow with fragrant decoction, uniting with the Cinnabar Prime Lord as one.

**Sacrifice to the Cinnabar Prime Lord:**
This is one’s own primordial spirit. The Primordial August One divides the body and descends qi into the self, becoming the master of one’s destiny. Use vegetarian offerings of tea, wine, and fruit on the day of one’s destiny-star and birth-star, placing them in a purified chamber. Visualize three figures bowing and yielding in seated posture.

**Incantation:**
*"Cinnabar Prime guards the void,
Inner and outer both true.
Three and seven on left and right,
Assist my bodily form.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by the Primordial Yang Master!"*

After the incantation, collect one portion each of golden coins and immortal cranes as offerings. Visualize oneself accompanied by sword- and axe-bearing attendants, or wielding flowing-gold fire bells. When the master moves, they appear ahead; when still, they stand behind; when seated, they remain at the sides. Within a hundred days, a red child will appear as an attendant at the left and right. If angered, they will distance themselves from others.

To inscribe the *Heming Talisman*, recite the talismanic incantation. Let the heart unite with the spirit, the spirit with qi, qi with the True, and yin with yang. As yang shines with the sun’s radiance, yin gleams with the moon’s luminance. The Three Heavens revolve in brightness, governing the workings of creation. The imperial True merges with the numinous, penetrating the profound and obscure. Like the sun’s ascent, it revolves boundlessly.

**Incantation:**
*"Heming Heavenly Thearch, sun and moon illuminate.
Seize spirits and summon ghosts, let True qi flow.
Five spirits wield swords, the Six Jia follow.
Divine lads lead the way, jade maidens convey the numinous.
Immortals assist—all endeavors succeed.
Should any dare disobey, report to the Imperial Lord.
Heavenly Thearch’s envoys, emerge from darkness into light.
Seize spirits and summon ghosts, swiftly make them appear.
The Heavenly Thearch protects me—no fear, no alarm.
The Three Terraces shine, soul and spirit at peace.
The Jade Thearch decrees, granting me long life.
Swiftly, swiftly, as decreed by the statutes!"*

**Method:**
This *Heming Talisman* may command the hundred spirits, restrain souls and subdue spirits, and present oneself before the imperial True. After concluding the audience with the officials, proceed with the ritual, holding the memorial and pacing the steps of the Dipper. Recite the preceding incantation and burn it in the main censer.

*The Eighteenth Scroll of the* Numinous Treasure Jade Mirror *concludes.*

*The Nineteenth Scroll of the* Numinous Treasure Jade Mirror:
*"Soaring Spirit to the Imperial Gate."*

The second tier is inscribed with the Eight Trigrams.
The third tier arranges the Azure Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, and Dark Warrior at the four directions.

**The Jade Mirror of the Numinous Treasure, Scroll Twenty**

**Flying to the Divine Gate to Audience the Emperor**
**The Nine Numinous Steps Ascending the Altar: Order of Rites**

The master, one month prior to establishing the retreat, refines and cultivates according to the method.

At the time of the rite, within the oratory, wear and bear all talismans. Then burn incense and prepare the knife, brush, cinnabar, ink, colored paper, yellow wax, ritual seals, and other offerings. Together with the retreat officers, inspect and verify the writ.

Thus, when the time comes, one avoids haste and displeasing the spirits.

The Radiant Court states: When mortals present memorials to the Emperor, they must compose themselves with solemn dignity, facing the proper direction to bow. Even the slightest deviation from protocol is deemed irreverent. How much more so for the august and revered Most High, where the celestial thoroughfares stretch vast and distant? Without utmost sincerity, one cannot reach the throne. One must focus the mind with unwavering devotion, observe rites with meticulous care, and follow all regulations without negligence. Only then can one assist the state and deliver the people, propagate and magnify the Dao, uphold the Heavenly Mandate, and perpetuate the ladder of goodness.

Next, the ritual implements are arrayed with dignity. The Dharma Master ascends the altar to perform the rites, while the retreat officers and Daoist assembly gather in the Hall of Contemplating the Real.

The Bell Master strikes the chime, and the Incense Grove expounds the Dharma of the Heavenly Worthy. Then, the assembly is called to order, and each pays reverence. The retreat officers are summoned to invite the master. The Master of Ceremonies conducts the rites and, on behalf of the retreat officers, delivers the invitation.

The High Master ascends the dais, offers incense, and expounds the Dao of traversing the void, racing the spirit, and riding the light.

The Bell Master invokes the Heavenly Worthy of Jade Clarity Who Sweeps Away Defilement, then recites the Sweeping Defilement Incantation. The Purification Master sprinkles and purifies. The Bell Master invokes the Heavenly Worthy of Golden Reality Who Proclaims the Teachings. The Censer Attendant leads the assembly to the altar.

Next, the chanting of the Dao begins.

The High Master establishes the boundary and circumambulates while burning incense. The attendant officers burn the Entering the Household Talisman.

Next turning east, he visualizes the Lords and Elders. Again facing south, he focuses on the Three Generals. Finally turning north, he visualizes the Most High Lord Lao. All the perfected beings merge together amidst clouds of blue, yellow, and white.

**Ascending in Spirit to the Emperor’s Gate: The Dipper-Stepping Method**

**On Jia Days:**
Step the Dipper beginning at the *zi* position. The Azure Dragon aligns with the day’s active Heavenly Gate direction.
For Jia days, invoke the names of the Heavenly Gate, Earthly Door deities, and Jade Maidens:
- Heavenly Gate Deity: Tian Ke
- Earthly Door Deity: Gongsun Qi
- Ding Jade Maiden: Shun Qi
- Geng Jade Maiden: Bai Jing
- Divine Marshal: Yuan, "Mighty Command"
- Merit Officer: Du, "Cultured Splendor"
- Youth: Yang, "Essence"
- Incense Official: Gui, "Pure Clerk"

Of these eight, the first four are called within the Dipper-stepping incantation; the remainder are inscribed in the memorial document.

**On Ji Days:**
Step the Dipper beginning at the *xu* position. The Azure Dragon aligns with the day’s active Heavenly Gate direction.
For Ji days, invoke the names of the Heavenly Gate, Earthly Door deities, and Jade Maidens:
- Heavenly Gate Deity: Xu, "Righteousness"
- Earthly Door Deity: Xu, "Permitted"

- Geng Jade Maiden: Jiang Gong
- Divine Marshal: Xiao, "Ziyuan"
- Merit Officer: Zi, "Hui Ji"
- Youth: Yin Jing
- Incense Official: Cong, "Changqing"

Of these eight, the first four are called within the Dipper-stepping incantation; the remainder are inscribed in the memorial document.

**On Yi and Geng Days:**
Step the Dipper beginning at the *shen* position. The Azure Dragon aligns with the day.
For Yi and Geng days, invoke the names of the Heavenly Gate, Earthly Door deities, and Jade Maidens:
- Heavenly Gate Deity: Sima, "Radiance"
- Earthly Door Deity: Shi, "War"
- Ding Jade Maiden: Cao, "Piao Zhi"
- Geng Jade Maiden: Qing Yao
On Yi days:
- Marshal: Ji, "Zhongwen"

- Youth: Zhen Jing

**On Bing and Xin Days:**

**Petition-Submitting Method:**
The Master regulates breath, the tongue presses the upper palate, and visualizes beneath the altar: a Purple Numinous Chariot with generals, officers, soldiers, and cavalry arriving from the ten directions. The adept boards the chariot and ascends.

Visualize the heavens above and the earth below, the four directions empty and silent.

**Mudra:**
Purple Cloud Chariot, revolving the earth’s axis,
Direct the white qi from the lower Cinnabar Field to ascend to the Mud Pill.
Presently, behold the Golden Gate and enter; only myriad golden rays illuminate the adept’s body, inside and out, crystalline and clear. Suddenly, a treasure pearl hangs in the void—here, the adept silently presents the matter at heart.

Upon completion, the pearl emits myriad rays of golden and jade light, illuminating all worlds in an instant. A perfected one approaches, takes the petition from the adept’s hand, and ascends to present it to the Supreme. After a moment, a Jade Youth delivers a secret report.

Then, announce what is heard. The adept performs three bows and withdraws, visualizing descent from the Heavenly Gate to the altar. Sensing true qi overflowing, with intention gather it into the lower Cinnabar Field. Silently recite the Petition-Reviewing Incantation, rise to perform three bows, and conclude the audience.

The Master then resumes the audience, restores the censer, and leads the Dao assembly down from the altar.

Upon completing the incantation, burn willow wood, gather the Celestial Stem’s qi, and blow it toward the heavens to disperse the qi of demonic defilement. Next, form the Five Thunder Seal: flash the eyes as lightning, let the ears emit thunder, and the nose exhale wind.

Visualize the Numinous Officials, Jade Maidens, Merit Officers, Scribes, and soldiers bearing and escorting the petition case, ascending to the clouds and heavens. Rinse the mouth with water, spray it upon the petition, and burn it with fierce fire. As the petition departs, take care not to treat it lightly.

Prostrate and sit evenly, the tongue pressing the upper palate. Then, visualize your own perfected self receiving the petition from the Jade Maiden’s hands, entering the Crimson Palace to meet the Great One of the Controller of Destinies—this is the Three Ones, like a lotus seed in size. Upon concluding the address, hold the breath, ascend from the palate to the Golden Chamber and Jade Chamber, entering the Grotto Chamber to present it to the Supreme Clarity. Upon completion, enter the Supreme Clarity, then the Highest Clarity, and finally the Jade Clarity’s Imperial Palace. Present each in turn.

Then, visualize the Nine Palaces emitting three-colored qi, blending within a single chamber to coalesce into the Three Honored Ones. From this, your own perfected self emerges, clad in ritual vestments as usual, exiting the Mud Pill. Follow the *Nine Numinous Scripture*’s instructions, perform the Flying Steps of the Nine Numinous, ascend the Three Heavenly Gates, and visualize the cloud petition’s sequential presentation, reverently awaiting the mysterious response.

If the Supreme Clarity approves, the Highest Clarity follows; if the Jade Clarity consents, the Jade Thearch descends.

Upon completion, visualize your own self returning as before to recline within the Cinnabar Palace, facing the Three Honored Ones before the Great One. At this point, forget form and await the fulfillment of the response before rising to announce it.

**Petition-Presenting Mudra:**
For matters of great import concerning the state and living beings, one must approach the Three Heavenly Gates below and complete the inner audience.

Visualize the Five Directions’ Great Numinous Yang of five colors forming luminous halos in their respective directions. The Three Heavens’ Great One’s Purple Clouds hang suspended, shading the entire body. Their light descends into the Mud Pill, revolving nine times to the left, nine times to the right within the heart, blending with the Imperial Abode, ascending and descending three times.

Then, visualize the heart emitting red qi, ascending to the heavens like a long rainbow. As usual, visualize the adept’s form entering the red qi, revolving and ascending for hundreds of miles until beholding the sun and moon’s Yellow Path intersecting—this is the stellar realm.

Next, proceed northwest for another thousand miles, where faint purple clouds appear in the distance—these are the Three Heavenly Gates. First, visit the Azure Dragon Palace to present the matter to the Supreme One of Primordial Life. Then, journey south to the Phoenix Tower’s pavilion below to report to the Host of the Dao and Virtue. Next, pass west to the Metal Tower’s pavilion below the Lesser Brilliance to present it to the Orthodox Heavenly Master and the Three Master Lords. Finally, return to the Central Palace and proceed to the Dark Obscurity Palace’s Northern Culmen True Gate below to present it to the Supreme One Great Thearch Lord.

Next, ascend to the Golden Portal’s towering jeweled hall to pay homage to the Supreme Thearch. Upon reaching the Jade Steps below, place the memorial upon the jade table, where it is received by the attendant numinous consorts—the Radiant Azure-Winged White Jade Maidens of Great Mystery and the Vermilion Phoenix Lads—who swiftly convey it to the throne. Here, one awaits the mysterious grace; at this stage, it is no longer mere visualization, for the intent must merge with non-action to attain it.

Unless one is a Yang Spirit Earth Immortal capable of commanding the numinous consorts of the Six Jia, one may not behold the Thearch. If, through inner audience with the Three Venerables of the Great One’s Mandated Spirits, one enters the Dao and transforms the primordial, then one is no longer confined to the celestial vaults—attainment lies within oneself, and one may thereby summon the Ten Heavens at will. Conclude the visualization as at the outset.

**Method for Inner Audience with the Supreme Thearch to Open the Gates**

At a point three *fen* inward from the space between the brows lies the Golden Terrace and Jade Portal. The left brow is the Yellow Portal Divine Master; the right brow, the Purple Gate General. One *cun* inward lies the Hall of Light; three *cun* inward, the Mud-Pellet Palace of the Great One, where the Thearch appears in imperial majesty. Two *cun* inward lies the Cavern Chamber of the Grand Clarity; four *cun* inward, the Palace of the Great Ultimate, where the Yellow Lord of the Dao is seen. Three *cun* inward lies the Palace of the Mysterious Elixir; above it, the Cinnabar Field Palace of the Great One, where a single Red Child resides. Five *cun* inward lies the Palace of the Supreme, where Lord Wang Chen is seen. Three *cun* further upward lies the Jade Clarity Palace, where the Jade Thearch resides, facing the Celestial Gate.

Bow nine times in the heart, presenting each matter in full. When the silent audience concludes, exit the hall and proceed to the cavern table. Bow in the heart and visualize with focused intent, imagining oneself upon the earth while directing the mind to pay homage beneath the Grand Clarity. First, arrange the opening of the Eight Outer Gates; when the time is right, enter the oratory. Determine the position of the Greater Yang and the Lunar General within the palace, then apply the general to the correct hour to assess victory over adversaries, as well as the punishments, clashes, comparisons, harms, cyclical signs, yin and yang, and the functions of the four celestial deities—thus crafting one’s calculations to discern auspicious signs amid adversity.

If the response has not yet descended, it is by decree of the Celestial Mandate, dispatched through the celestial stars and employed by the celestial generals. Follow their governance, assemble the mighty incantations, and exhaust the subtle words of supplication to obtain a manifest reply. Should one divulge these secrets, the Three Officials will examine and punish, subjecting one to three interrogations and three investigations.

For those who wish to transmit and receive this teaching, one must swear an oath before Heaven, draw blood from the five centers, and present nine taels of purple gold to the lineage master, who will carefully examine the recipient before imparting it. Without oath or faith, the offense is equal to careless disclosure.

The essence of the inner audience, the form and demeanor of the Supreme Thearch, and the Nine Palaces of the Great Cavern Jade Chamber are transmitted orally.

Enter stillness and scrutinize the memorial.

First burn incense, gather the spirit, and sit upright, using the child to guard the mother. The spirit is the child of qi, and qi is the mother of the spirit; with each inhalation and exhalation, the spirit governs them. Up and down they circulate, issuing and entering in an unbroken stream. By day, open the ears and close the eyes; by night, open the eyes and close the ears. Whenever the heart stirs, whether the thought is inward or outward, suppress it with the heart, saying, "I am engaged in such-and-such a matter, not this thought." Count the breaths for a time: at first, the heart is more often stirred and less often still, thoughts of myriad conditions and ten thousand realms arise. Next, the heart is less often still and more often stirred—gather the heart into stillness. Then, movement and stillness are evenly matched, gradually progressing. Fourth, the heart is more often still and less often stirred, until it becomes wholly so; spirit and qi unite, breath and embryo merge, the heart is still and purely so. Only then may a single thought arise for some matter, but first practice silent audience. Once silent audience is thoroughly mastered, one may perform silent audience. This is the time for prostrating with the memorial; having ingested the heart-memorial, one also performs silent audience to scrutinize the memorial. During absorption, silent audience reveals visions, from which one discerns the imperial intent within the memorial. This is what is meant by "one’s own Heavenly Worthy—why trouble the Supreme August One?" *Oral transmission: □□□□□□, swiftly convey the words here. □□□□□□□, swiftly convey the words here. □□□□□□, swiftly convey the words here. □□□□□□, swiftly convey the words here.*

**Method for Scrutinizing the Memorial**
Enter stillness, visualize the Nine Palaces shining brightly, and perform the inner audience before the honored one. By day, close the eyes and focus the ears; by night, block the ears and close the eyes. Externally, visualize the officials of the memorial arrayed before you, with paper and brush placed upon the table. The heart-moon gazes toward them, the central Upper Palace connected within. Breath is tranquil, qi is even; forget form, depart from defilement. If the heart stirs, if the eyes see, if the ears hear—whether it be the Merit Officers, Jade Maidens, Heavenly Officials, or celestial spirits—whatever is spoken, whatever is revealed to the cinnabar origin, whatever is perceived by the numinous consorts, whatever messages are reported, may be recorded.

**Method for Absorption of the Perfected**
The Dao is non-action, yet nothing is left undone.
One may settle the heart, but not through clever knowing.
What is knowing? What is correctness?
Abandon knowledge, and evidence responds to emptiness.
If response has no source, emptiness then flows.
Flowing into the One, all matters are complete.
The One is the root; affairs have no gate.
Affairs return to the One; the One abides constantly.
Abiding—yet there is nothing; one borrows words to guard it.
Guard the empty and non-existent, and it endures forever.
Awaken to impermanence, and the Dao may endure.
Dwell in blandness within, and virtue grows ever greater.
Internally conceal fierceness; externally manifest majestic virtue.
Forget form and thought; dissolve the heart’s sincerity.
When form is free of dust, the heart is naturally true.
In the midst of sound, stillness; the heart gains stability.
Fragrance and stench as one; the heart unites with emptiness.
Sweet and bitter as one; the heart turns solid.
The body seems forgotten; the heart does not fall.
Thoughts do not scatter; the heart does not disperse.
Ever serene, correctness is wholly preserved.
Use without limit; act by forgetting the means.

**Examples for Scrutinizing the Memorial**
All round objects: no harm.
All non-round objects: harm.
All living, verdant things: life.
All withered, desiccated things: death.
All grains with ears: all unfulfilled.
All broken, incomplete things: all unfulfilled.
All coffins, tombs, and burial mounds: all inauspicious.
Much auspiciousness.

Joy.

All windows, lattices, bowls, and cups: all mouths.
Fists signify power.
All towers, pavilions, stairways, steps, and terraces: all growth.
All bamboo slips: all calculations.
Broken: broken.
Unnecessary: all removed.
Hands: guarding.
On horseback, mirrors, all red and crimson hues: all transgressions.
Bells: longevity.

Water as one, fire as two, wood as three, metal as four, earth as five: all life.
Water as six, fire as seven, wood as eight, metal as nine, earth as ten: then completion.

Tall trees: loftiness.
Combs: lowliness.
Women in brocade robes: peace.
Saddles: peace.

The method lies in extending by analogy—now shaping through form, now resonating through qi, responding with the heart, awakening in thought, realizing in intent. The spirit’s resonance conveys emotion, subtly penetrating profound understanding, never departing from one’s own spirit.

Wine should not be drunk in excess; pungent flavors should not be eaten. Thoughts should not be divided; intent should not be scattered. Thus may the celestial mechanism be accessed.

**Examples of Correspondences**
Hearing shouts, wails, cries of anger, or thunderous roars.

**Ominous.**
Hearing the sounds of metal, jade, flutes, horns, strings, or bamboo instruments: **auspicious.**
Hearing the sounds of water, fire, striking, crashing, or collapse: **inauspicious.**
Smelling blood, stench, or filth: **greatly ominous.**
Scenting rare fragrances or hearing divine beings speak: **auspicious.**
Seeing blood, light, or black qi: **ominous.**
If the vision remains unclear or the spirit fails to appear repeatedly: **a sign of misfortune.**
Unfavorable.

**Examples of Correspondences**
For praying for rain: seeing aquatic creatures or hearing the sound of water: **auspicious.**
For healing illness: seeing the construction of a house, the chopping of wood, round objects, open doors, obtaining tallies, green objects, or an east wind: **auspicious.**
For offering to the deceased: sweet rain, yellow light, celestial gates, ladders, boats, or bridges: **auspicious.**

The method requires further invocation, further scrutiny, further verification. Amidst the ten thousand transformations and thousandfold complexities, through careful inquiry and open discourse, divine beings will reveal all to humanity.

Upon the Jade Capital,
A jeweled terrace hangs in layers,
Unscalable by steps.
Now I come to expound the teaching,
One layer upon another.
The nature of heaven is free of obscurity,
Within it abide precepts, concentration, and wisdom.
A single point, most perfectly luminous,
Like the autumn moon on a mid-autumn night.

*Lingbao Yujian*, Scroll Twenty-One: **Complete**
*Lingbao Yujian*, Scroll Twenty-Two

**The Gate of Talismans and Registers**

The Dao transforms once to become the Law, for the Law is the application of the Dao. Yet the Dao as the essence of the Law is omnipresent, though in daily use it goes unrecognized. As the scriptures say, the Dao’s presence in the world is like rivers and valleys flowing into the great seas. So too is the primordial *qi*. Among the ten thousand methods, which does not arise from this?

Thus, the Great Law of Lingbao encompasses talismans, registers, writs, and decrees—each with its own origin. In ancient times, the Sovereign traced brushstrokes, eight-cornered rays descending, called "phoenix scripts" and "dragon charts," or "golden writings" and "jade characters," all ancient celestial methods of heaven and humanity. The talisman (*fu*) unites with the numinous; the register (*lu*) records merit; the writ (*jian*) sets forth words; the decree (*gao*) issues commands. All derive from the primordial *qi* of the Law’s origin, merging with the wondrous radiance of Lingbao to summon spirits and manifest the divine. Inscribed on bamboo, silk, gold, jade, cinnabar, or paper, they reveal the hidden and illuminate the dark, dispelling the long night. Holding the talisman and grasping the register, one oversees the true and delivers the living—embodying the marvel of natural spirit-transformation and mysterious communion.

Those who proclaim and practice this teaching must cultivate stillness, emptiness, and unity, focusing the mind and concentrating the spirit. Penetrating the obscure and the luminous, merging inner and outer, one’s Dharma-nature and primordial spirit become the original true body of the Primordial Beginning. Every stroke and line is the golden radiance of the Dao’s *qi*. Thus, nothing remains unpervaded, and none go undelivered. What more is there to the essence and function of Dao and Law?

**Invoking and Presenting the Talismans**

The officiant, with reverence, burns precious incense and solemnly petitions the Three Pure Ones of the Great Dao, the Ten Lofty Perfected, the Founding Masters of the Teaching, and the officials of the Three Realms. May the Dao’s compassion deign to gaze upon this offering.

Now, as the altar is opened for the annual rites, the sacred statutes of Lingbao must be strictly observed. To relieve suffering and deliver the deceased, we rely upon the radiant *qi* of the Mysterious Origin. Though this humble servant remains dull and unrefined, unversed in subtleties, I fear my talisman-writing may not accord with the celestial pattern. Thus, I earnestly beseech the true mandate. May the attending immortals be commanded to reveal their treasuries, bestowing upon this petty officer the authority to proclaim it universally, that all may follow without hindrance. May the multitudes be delivered, ascending at once. This servant, daring to offend celestial majesty, awaits the command with utmost urgency.

**Writing Talismans and Practicing the Method**

When inscribing any talisman, one must first enter the oratory (*jing*), preparing incense, lamps, paper, brushes, inkstones, and all necessary implements. Begin with the inner refinement of the "Ten Cycles of Returning the Numinous."

The master sits in stillness, regulating the breath until spirit and *qi* settle into emptiness. Visualize the Lingbao primordial *qi* of the ancestral origin within the Abyssal Spring Palace of the lower cinnabar field. From there, it ascends through the twenty-four nodes, piercing the mud-pill palace at the crown of the head, then descends back to the original palace, cycling ten times.

Next, visualize the Three Fields, each containing a Perfected One, riding clouds of three colors. They ascend to sit within the mud-pill. Then, from the heavens, three-colored clouds bearing three Perfected Ones descend into the mud-pill, merging into one. This must be vividly clear. The Lord of the Cinnabar Origin ascends to present the petition. Soon, the merciful countenance grants approval. The command is issued to the attendant immortals—golden lads and jade maidens—who descend bearing a jade case and a precious tome within a radiance of a hundred treasures, entrusting them to the servant for execution. Silently expressing gratitude, one’s true self emits a treasure-light, merging with the spirit-*qi*. Inner and outer become luminously clear. Phoenix scripts and dragon charts swirl above the desk. Knock the teeth twelve times.

**Supreme Precious Register for Ascension to Heaven—Edict of Liberation—Proclamation Issued**

To the Overseers of the Ten Directions, the Three Realms, and the Nine Netherworlds:

In reverent compliance with the edict of the Supreme Lord, all transgressions of the departed [name], along with the six paths of rebirth, the four kinds of existence, the fox spirits of the nine provinces, the male and female souls of the underworld, and those suffering boundless torment in the prisons—from the kalpas of old until this very day—shall be pardoned. All grave sins of the three karmas and six senses, whether:

Unfilial to parents,
Slandering the Great Dao, forsaking truth for falsehood,
Harming siblings, betraying masters,
Colluding with kin in incestuous transgressions,
Robbing and murdering, slaughtering living beings for self-gain,
Bullying the weak, oppressing the lowly,
Feigning devotion to the Three Treasures while lacking sincerity,
Disrespecting Dharma masters, defiling sacred scriptures,
Harboring malice, nurturing envy and cruelty,
Engaging in slander, sowing discord among the virtuous,
Killing for sacrifices, exposing the Three Luminaries to defilement,
Or sins born of thought, speech, personal action, or incitement of others—

All such offenses, accumulated over countless kalpas, boundless in measure, shall now be absolved according to their weight. They are to be delivered and liberated, their sins expunged, their enmities resolved. Freed from hell, they shall behold the light; their myriad transgressions dissolved, they shall ascend to the ritual altar, receive salvation, and be transformed.

The souls thus delivered shall:
Refine the seven *qi* into perfection,
Orbit the six celestial motions in emptiness,
Weave the five numinous threads to completion,
Draw strength from the twin luminaries,
Traverse the void with the turning Big Dipper,
Ascend to the cloud palaces,
Where life begins in the womb and kalpas know no end.

Their essence shall gestate in golden citadels,
Their spirits congeal in jade grottoes,
Nurtured by true *qi* within to become perfected beings.
Above, they shall enter the Great Void;
Below, they shall traverse the nether springs.
Within the cloud palaces’ jeweled towers, their true souls shall dwell,
Moving freely through the land of blessings,
Roaming the gates of rebirth,
Feasting on sacred mushrooms,
Sipping from golden springs,
Bathed in flowing ambrosia,
Their cinnabar fields brimming with suspended elixirs.
Purple auroras shall dawn upon them,
The three *qi* shall condense into mist.
Their jade chambers shall transform them into immortals,
Seated upon golden lotuses.
Their true forms shall eclipse the sun,
And kalpas shall pass as years.

As this edict commands, let it be transmitted by wind and fire.
